PT J
AN ZOOR14708055192
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI The littoral and shallow-water barnacles (Crustacea: Cirripedia) of
   south-eastern Queensland.
AU Jones, Diana S. (diana.jones@museum.wa.gov.au) 
SO Memoirs of the Queensland Museum
VL 54
IS 3
PS 199-233
PD 30 December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Seventy-four littoral and shallow-water (0-100 m) barnacle species from
   south-eastern Queensland are documented. Data from new collections of
   littoral and shallow-water barnacle species made during the February
   2005 workshop, are combined with older SE Queensland barnacle collection
   data from Australian museums. South-eastern Queensland represents a
   transitional area between southern temperate and tropical zones and this
   transitional position is reflected in the composition of the barnacle
   fauna. The number of Australian endemic species (12) is relatively high,
   reflecting the influence of the southern fauna, but the fauna is
   dominated by species with Indo-west Pacific (25), cosmopolitan (22) and,
   to a lesser extent, Indo-Japanese (9) affinities, with Australasian (2),
   western Pacific (2) and Indo-Australasian (1) species minor components.
   One new species, Arcalepas brucei Jones & Morton, 2009, was collected
   during the Workshop. Neonrosella subgen. nov. is proposed to replace
   Rosella Ross & Perreault, 1999, which is preoccupied.
C1 Jones, Diana S.; Western Australian Museum, 49 Kew St, Welshpool, WA,
   Australia, Australia.
EM diana.jones@museum.wa.gov.au
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology

   Pacific Ocean

   species (Coleoptera: Cicindelidae).
AU Wiesner, Juergen (juergen.wiesner@wolfsburg.de)

PS 133-140
PD 30 Dezember 2010

LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Naviauxella shooki n. sp. is described. It is distinguished by unique
   elytral maculations, colour of labrum and shape of aedeagus. Calochroa
   cariana (Gestro, 1893), Cylindera (Ifasina) viridilabris (Chaudoir,
   1852) and Cylindera (Ifasina) spinolae koratensis Naviaux, 1991 are
   recorded for the first time from the province of Chiang Mai. Cylindera
   (Ifasina) kaleea kaleea (Bates, 1863) is recorded for the first time
   from Thailand.

AN ZOOR14705034175
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Additions to the fossil dragonfly fauna from the Lower Cretaceous Crato
   Formation of Brazil (Insecta: Odonata).
AU Bechly, Guenter (guenter.bechly@smns-bw.de) 
SO Palaeodiversity
VL 3
SU (Supplement 1-2)
PS 11-77
PD 30 December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Several interesting new discoveries of fossil odonates from the Lower
   Cretaceous Crato Formation of NE Brazil are presented. Two new taxa of
   damselflies (Euarchistigma peterknobli n. sp. and Santanagrion longipes
   n. gen., n. sp.) are described, and a new specimen of Euarchistigma
   marialuiseae with preserved colour pattern, distinct from the type
   species, is featured. Among the dragonflies totally three new families
   (Megaphlebiidae n. fam., Magnathemidae n. fam., and Cratopetaliidae n.
   fam.), nine new genera, and ten new species (Paracordulagomphus aberrans
   n. gen., n. sp.; Paracordulagomphus divergens n. gen., n. sp.;
   Pauciphlebia novaolindense n. gen., n. sp.; Cratogomphus erraticus n.
   gen., n. sp.; Cratohagenius erichweberi n. gen., n. sp.; Megaphlebia
   rayandressi n. gen., n. sp.; Magnathemis marcusthorhalli n. gen., n.
   sp.; and Cratopetalia whiteheadi n. gen., n. sp.) are described. A
   further putative new dragonfly genus and species is discussed and
   featured, but not formally described because of the poor preservation of
   the single available specimen. The original descriptions of
   Euarchistigma marialuiseae, Cratostenophlebia schwickerti, Eotanypteryx
   paradoxa, Paramesuropetala gigantea, Cordulagomphus hanneloreae and
   Cordulagomphus winkelhoferi are emended with new data and supplemented
   with drawings and photos. The newly discovered counter plate of the
   holotype of Cratopetalura petruleviciusi is featured. Some errors
   concerning collection numbers and depositions of fossil odonates in
   MARTILL et al. (2007) are corrected and new collection numbers are
   updated for the Senckenberg museum collection.
C1 Bechly, Guenter; Staatl Museum Nat Kunde Stuttgart, Rosenstein 1,
   D-70191 Stuttgart, Germany, Germany.
EM guenter.bechly@smns-bw.de

   South America; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

PT J
AN ZOOR14704030516
DT Article
TI A New Genus of the Spider Family Caponiidae (Araneae, Haplogynae) from
   the West Indies.
AU Sanchez-Ruiz, Alexander (alex@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu) 
   Platnick, Norman I.
   Duperre, Nadine
SO American Museum Novitates
VL 3705
PS 1-44
PD Dec 29 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new genus, Cubanops, is established for a distinctive group of
   caponiid spiders from the West Indies. Nops ludovicorum Alayon, from
   Cuba, and Caponina darlingtoni Bryant, from Hispaniola, are transferred
   to Cubanops. Nine new species are described from the Bahama Islands (C.
   bimini, C. andersoni), Cuba (C. armasi, C. alayoni, C. juragua, C.
   granpiedra, C. terueli, C. tortuguilla), and Hispaniola (C. vega). All
   these species are nopines (i.e., have subsegmented tarsi) and have the
   ventral translucent keel on the anterior metatarsi, and the translucent
   extension of the membrane between the anterior metatarsi and tarsi, that
   are also found in the genera Nops MacLeay, Orthonops Chamberlin, and
   Tarsonops Chamberlin. However, Cuba flops species lack the dorsally
   extended inferior claw found in Nops, and differ from those of Orthonops
   and Tarsonops in having a distinctly patterned carapace, a widened
   labium, and bisegmented metatarsi IV. Two species groups are recognized
   within the genus, which probably occurs also in Puerto Rico and the
   Virgin Islands, as juveniles with these somatic characters have been
   taken on St. John.
C1 Sanchez-Ruiz, Alexander; Museo Hist Nat Tomas Romay, Ctr Oriental
   Ecosistemas & Biodiversidad, Santiago De Cuba, Cuba.
EM alex@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu
RI Ruiz, Alexander Sanchez/Q-4490-2016
OI Ruiz, Alexander Sanchez/0000-0001-8204-2041
SC Zoology
SN 0003-0082; 1937-352X

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   Central America; West Indies

DT Article
TI THE STONEFLY GENUS LEDNIA IN NORTH AMERICA (PLECOPTERA: NEMOURIDAE).
AU Baumann, Richard W. (richard_baumann@byu.edu) 
   Kondratieff, Boris C.
SO Illiesia
VL 6
IS 25
PS 315-327
PD 28 December 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www2.pms-lj.si/illiesia/papers/Illiesia06-25.pdf
AW http://www2.pms-lj.si/illiesia/papers/Illiesia06-25.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The nemourid genus Lednia is characterized in the male, female and
   larval stages. Two new species are described, L. borealis and L. sierra.
   Illustrations are provided as line drawings and scanning electron
   microscope images for the adult stages. Three Lednia species are
   presently known from western North America: L. borealis, Cascade Range,
   Washington; L. tumana, northern Rocky Mountains and L. sierra, Sierra
   Nevada, California.
C1 Baumann, Richard W.; Department of Biology and Monte L. Bean Life
   Science Museum, Brigham Young University, Provo, UT, 84602, USA, USA.

AB Two new geometrid species, Arichanna vernalis Fu & Sato, sp. nov. and
   Lassaba hsuhonglini Fu & Sato, sp. nov., are described from Taiwan. They
   are found mainly in high mountain ranges and fly in early spring. The
   female of L. tayulingensis (Sato), a close relative of the latter new
   species, is described for the first time.

PT J
AN ZOOR14704030566
DT Article
TI Review of the genus Nannoarctia Koda, s. str. (Lepidoptera, Arctiidae).
AU Dubatolov, Vladimir V.
   Kishida, Yasunori
SO Tinea
VL 21
IS 3
PS 136-152
PD 25 December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The nominotypical subgenus Nannoarctia Koda, 1988 is discussed. The type
   species of the genus should be changed to N. takanoi Sonan, 1934, based
   on incorrect determination by Koda, 1988. Species of this group have few
   distinguishing characters in the male genitalia and are better separated
   by the wing pattern. Six species are recognized, and one species and
   three subspecies are described as new: N. himalayana spec. nov. from the
   Himalayas, N. conjuncta sumbana subsp. nov. from Sumba and Sumbawa, N.
   c. javanica subsp. nov. from Java, N. h. nepalica subsp. nov. from Nepal
   and East India. Lectotypes are designated for: N. c. williami
   (Rothschild, 1910) from Bali, N. tripartita (Walker, 1855) from Burma,
   Moulmein, and N. obliquifascia (Hampson, 1894) from Burma, Rangoon.
C1 Dubatolov, Vladimir V.; Siberian Zoological Museum, Institute of Animal
   Systematics and Ecology, Frunze street, 11, Novosibirsk, 630091, Russia,
   Russia.
SC Zoology
SN 0493-3168
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Taxonomy; Status; Land zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Nannoarctia (Nannoarctia) [Asia /  / Distribution; systematics]. 
   Nannoarctia (Nannoarctia) conjuncta javanica; Nannoarctia (Nannoarctia)
   conjuncta sumbana [Indonesia /  / New subspecies]. 
   Nannoarctia (Nannoarctia) himalayana [Assam /  / New species] [Himachal
   Pradesh /  / ] [Uttar Pradesh /  / ] [Nepal /  / ].

DT Article
TI A new genus and species of herminiine moth (Noctuidae) from the Yaeyama
   Islands, the Ryukyus, Japan.
AU Owada, Mamoru
SO Tinea
VL 21
IS 3
PS 157-160
PD 25 December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A noctuid herminiine moth, Hywoolla jeremyi Owada, gen. et sp. nov., is
   described from the Yaeyama Islands, the Ryukyus, Japan. The genus
   Hywoolla is characterized by the unique specialization of the male
   forelegs and hindlegs, and the type species of the genus is Hywoolla
   jeremyi. Other members of Hywoolla are H. adda (Swinhoe, 1902), comb.
   nov., from Malay Peninsula and Borneo, H. albapex (Hampson, 1895), comb.
   nov., from the Himalayas, Sri Lanka, Borneo and Bangka Is., and H.
   stidzeras (Holloway, 2008), comb. nov., from Borneo.
C1 Owada, Mamoru; Department of Zoology, National Museum of Nature and
   Science, Hyakunin-cho 3-23-1, Shinjuku, Tokyo, 169-0073, Japan, Japan.

SN 0493-3168

   position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   Noctuoidea, Noctuidae
OR Hywoolla (Noctuidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Herminiinae, Type species
   Hywoolla jeremyi, p. 157]. 
   Hywoolla adda - (Swinhoe 1902) (Noctuidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Zanclognatha, p. 158]. 
   Hywoolla albapex - (Hampson 1895) (Noctuidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Nodaria, p. 158].

TI Notes on Catocala agitatrix Graeser, 1888 (1889) group (Lepidoptera,
   Noctuidae).
AU Ishizuka, Katsumi
SO Tinea
VL 21
IS 3
PS 161-170
PD 25 December 2010
PY 2010
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Catocala agitatrix group are revised. C. mabella Holland, formerly
   treated as a synonym or subspecies of C. agitatrix Graeser, is revealed
   to be an independent species being disrtibuted in Japan. Two new
   subspecies are described as follows: C. mabella kobayashii ssp. nov.
   from Hokkaido (Japan); C. agitatrix shaanxiensis ssp. nov. from Korea
   and China.

PT J
AN ZOOR14702019566
DT Article
TI New species of black flies (Diptera: Simuliidae) from Nepal.
AU Takaoka, Hiroyuki (takaoka@med.oita-u.ac.jp) 
   Shrestha, Suchitra
SO Zootaxa
VL 2731
PS 1-62
PD 24 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02731p062.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02731p062.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Ten new species of black flies are described based on larval, pupal and
   reared adult specimens collected at various localities in Nepal. All new
   species are assigned to the genus Simulium Latreille and further
   classified into five subgenera: one (S. suchitrae sp. nov.) in
   Asiosimulium Takaoka & Choochote, one (S. jomsomense sp. nov.) in
   Eusimulium Roubaud, three (S. baglungense sp. nov., S. butwalense sp.
   nov., S. nuwakotense sp. nov.) in Gomphostilbia Enderlein, two (S.
   lekhaniense sp. nov., S. letense sp. nov.) in Nevermannia Enderlein, and
   three (S. titarense sp. nov., S. tamorense sp. nov., S. tulshii sp.
   nov.) in Simulium Latreille s. str. Among these, the first two new
   species also represnt new records from Nepal of two subgenera,
   Asiosimulium and Eusimulium, respectively, both of which occur very
   rarely in the Oriental Region. The previous record from Nepal of S. (G.)
   gombakense Takaoka & Davies is corrected to that of S. (G.) sachini
   Takaoka & Henry, recently described from India. The male and mature
   larva of S. (G.) sachini are also described for the first time. The
   taxonomic affinities with related known species, if any, are noted for
   each new species. The keys to all 32 Nepalese species of black flies are
   provided.
C1 Takaoka, Hiroyuki; Department of Infectious Disease Control, Faculty of
   Medicine, Oita University, Yufu City, Oita, 879-5593, Japan, Japan.
EM takaoka@med.oita-u.ac.jp
RI Takaoka, Hiroyuki/G-6120-2010
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Simulium [Nepal /  / Key to species]. 
   Simulium (Asiosimulium) suchitrae; Simulium (Eusimulium) jomnomense;
   Simulium (Gomphostilbia) baglungense; Simulium (Gomphostilbia)
   butwalense; Simulium (Gomphostilbia) nuwakotense; Simulium (Nevermannia)
   lekhaniense; Simulium (Nevermannia) letense; Simulium (Simulium)
   tamorense; Simulium (Simulium) titarense; Simulium (Simulium) tulshii
   [Nepal /  / New species]. 
   Simulium (Gomphostilbia) gombakense [Nepal /  / Erroneous record]. 
   Simulium (Gomphostilbia) sachini [Nepal /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Simuliidae
OR Simulium (Simuliidae): [Key to species, Nepal, Females, p. 56; Key to

   Nepal, Mature larvae, p. 58]. 
   Simulium (Asiosimulium) suchitrae - Takaoka 2010 (Simuliidae): [Sp nov,
   Nepal, P. 4]. 
   Simulium (Eusimulium) jomnomense (Simuliidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P. 8]. 
   Simulium (Gomphostilbia) baglungense (Simuliidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P.
   15]. 
   Simulium (Gomphostilbia) butwalense (Simuliidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P.

   Simulium (Gomphostilbia) nuwakotense (Simuliidae): [Sp nov, Nepal, P.
   23].

PT J
AN ZOOR14702019561
DT Article
TI Tanaidacea (Crustacea, Peracarida) of the North-east Atlantic: the
   Agathotanaidae of the AFEN, BIOFAR and BIOICE projects, with a
   description of a new species of Paragathotanais Lang.
AU Bird, Graham J. (zeuxo@clear.net.nz) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2730
PS 1-22
PD 24 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2730.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02730p022.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The tanaidacean fauna of the Iceland-Faroes-Shetlands sector of the
   North-east Atlantic was studied using material from the BIOFAR, BIOICE
   and AFEN surveys. Seven agathotanaid species were recorded from the
   genera Agathotanais, Paragathotanais and Paranarthrura, a total
   comparable to those from a similar bathymetric range in the
   Rockall-Biscay area and the Gulf of Mexico. A new species of
   Paragathotanais is described. All records of this family were from
   benthic stations with a mean bottom temperature of >=2[degree]C, with
   none from the 'cold-water' region north of the Iceland-Shetlands ridge
   complex. An analysis of North-east Atlantic agathotanaid sex-ratios
   shows that these are not highly skewed in favour of females and are
   consistent with the status of the males as relatively non-dimorphic and
   long-lived entities.
C1 Bird, Graham J.; Valley View, 8 Shotover Grove, Waikanae, Kapiti Coast,
   5036, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM zeuxo@clear.net.nz
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Ecology; Population
   dynamics; Population structure; Distribution within habitat; Marine
   zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Agathotanaidae [Population sex ratio /  / new record; systematics]
   [Vertical distribution / Bathymetric distribution / ] [North Atlantic /
   Iceland-Faroes-Shetlands sector / Key to species] [ / North east /
   distribution]. 
   Paragathotanais vikingus [North Atlantic /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Tanaidacea
OR Agathotanaidae - Lang 1971 (Tanaidacea): [Key to species, North
   Atlantic, Iceland-Faroes-Shetlands sector, P. 14; New record]. 
   Paragathotanais vikingus (Tanaidacea): [Sp nov, North Atlantic, P. 7]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14702019561
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14702019563
DT Article
TI Clubionidae from Laos and Thailand (Arachnida: Araneae).
AU Jaeger, Peter (peter.jaeger@senckenberg.de) 
   Dankittipakul, Pakawin
SO Zootaxa
VL 2730
PS 23-43
PD 24 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2730.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02730p043.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Clubionidae collected in Laos and Thailand were investigated. Seven new
   species are described: Clubiona kai spec. nov.(male: Laos, Luang Prabang
   Prov.), Clubiona lala spec. nov. (female: Laos, Luang Nam Tha Prov.),
   Clubiona maipaispec. nov. (male: Thailand, Mae Hong Son Prov.), Clubiona
   kuu spec. nov. (male: Laos, Luang Prabang Prov.), Clubiona vukomi spec.
   nov. (male: Laos, Luang Nam Tha Prov.), Malamatidia zu spec. nov. (male:
   Laos, Luang Prabang Prov.) and Malamatidia christae spec. nov. (female:
   Laos, Luang Nam Tha Prov.). The genus Malamatidia, previously known from
   Sumatra, Sarawak, the Malaysian peninsular, Kalimantan, and Sulawesi is
   recorded from Laos (Luang Nam Tha Province) as northernmost distribution
   locality and is re-diagnosed. Cheiracanthium insulanum (Thorell, 1878),
   Cheiracanthium unicum Boesenberg and Strand, 1906, Clubiona abnormis
   Dankittipakul, 2008, Clubiona filicata O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1874,
   Clubiona melanothele Thorell, 1895 are recorded for the first time from
   Laos. Cheiracanthium insulanum, Clubiona abnormis, and Clubiona
   melanothele are additionally illustrated. A map with all records is
   provided.
C1 Jaeger, Peter; Arachnology, Research Institute Senckenberg,
   Senckenberganlage 25, D-60325 Frankfurt am Main, Germany, Germany.
EM peter.jaeger@senckenberg.de

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   record].

   Malamatidia zu [Laos /  / New species]. 
   Clubiona maipai [Thailand /  / New species]. 
   Clubiona vukomi [Laos /  / New species] [Thailand /  / ]. 
   Clubionidae [Laos /  / New record; systematics] [Thailand /  / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates

   Cheiracanthium unicum (Araneae): [New record].

   New record].

TI A new cave-dwelling species of Cyrtodactylus Gray, 1827 (Squamata:
   Gekkonidae) from Khammouane Province, southern Laos.
AU Ngo, Van Tri (trigeckonid@hotmail.com)

VL 2730
PS 44-56
PD 24 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2730.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02730p056.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new cave-dwelling bent-toed gecko, Cyrtodactylus lomyenensis sp. nov.
   is described from a karst forest in Gnommalath District, Khammouane
   Province, southern Laos. It differs from all other species of
   Indochinese-Thai Cyrtodactylus in the following combination of
   characters: maximum SVL of at least 71.2 mm; head dorsum yellowish with
   irregular brown blotches; presence of a brown nuchal loop reaching the
   posterior edge of the orbit; four narrow yellowish[long dash]cream
   transversal bands with irregular anterior and posterior black edges on a
   brown background between limb insertions; no precloacal groove; 39[long
   dash]40 precloacal-femoral pores in males, arranged in a continuous row;
   females with 32 precloacal[long dash]femoral pores in a continuous row,
   smaller than those of males; five postanal tubercles on each side;
   16[long dash]18 subdigital lamellae on first toe; 19[long dash]23
   subdigital lamellae on fourth toe; no tubercles on tail dorsum; and a
   median row of enlarged subcaudal scales.
C1 Ngo, Van Tri; Department of Environmental Management and Technology,
   Institute of Tropical Biology, Vietnamese Academy of Sciences and
   Technology, 85 Tran Quoc Toan Street, District 3, Ho Chi Minh City,
   Vietnam, Vietnam.

   Peninsula are diagnosed, described, and illustrated, i.e., Cataleptoneta

DT Article
TI A revision of the Hawaiian and Wake Island species of the genus
   Conchopus Takagi (Diptera, Dolichopodidae).
AU Masunaga, Kazuhiro (moai@lbm.go.jp) 
   Saigusa, Toyohei
SO Zootaxa
VL 2729
PS 1-35
PD 23 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2729.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02729p035.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Six shore-dwelling species of the rectus group of the genus Conchopus
   Takagi are recognized from the Hawaiian and Wake Islands, including five
   new species. Conchopus is restricted to this species group herein.
   Contrary to some earlier records, C. acrosticalis (Parent, 1937) occurs
   only on four of the Hawaiian Islands (Hawai'i, Maui, Lana'i, and
   Moloka'i). The new species are distributed as follows: C. ciliatus sp.
   nov. (Hawai'i, Maui, O'ahu and Lisianski Is.); C. crassinervis sp. nov.
   (Kaua'i); C. minutus sp. nov. (Hawai'i, Maui, Lana'i, O'ahu, and French
   Frigate Shoals); C. menehune sp. nov. (Kaua'i and Nihoa Is.); and C.
   pacificus sp. nov. (Hawai'i, O'ahu, Kaua'i, and Wake Is). A key to the
   males of all known species of the rectus group is provided.
C1 Masunaga, Kazuhiro; Lake Biwa Museum, Oroshimo 1091, Kusatsu, Shiga,
   525-0001, Japan, Japan.
EM moai@lbm.go.jp

   [Hawaii /  / ].

DT Article
TI A new species from southwestern China of the Holarctic genus
   Odontothrips (Thysanoptera: Thripidae).
AU Xie, Yonghui
   Zhang, Hongrui (hongruizh@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Mound, Laurence A.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2729
PS 53-57
PD 23 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2729.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02729p057.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Odontothrips yunnanensis sp.n. is described from Yunnan in Southwestern
   China. Unlike most species of this Holarctic genus, the fore tarsi and
   fore tibiae do not have any teeth. The base of the sensorium on the
   sixth antennal segment is more than half as long as the total length of
   this sensorium, as is typical of species in the genera Odontothrips and
   Odontothrip- iella. In contrast, species of the Asian tropical genus
   Megalurothrips have the base of this sensorium less than 0.3 as long as
   the sensorium. Almost all species in these three genera breed only in
   flowers of Fabaceae. Males of this new species bear on tergum IX a pair
   of stout sigmoid processes.
C1 Zhang, Hongrui; Ministry of Education, Key Laboratory of Agriculture
   Biodiversity and Pest Management, Kunming, 650201, China, China.
EM hongruizh@yahoo.com.cn
RI Mound, Laurence A/A-3967-2009
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Odontothrips yunnanensis [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Thysanoptera
OR Odontothrips (Thysanoptera): [Systematic relationships, P. 53]. 
   Odontothrips yunnanensis (Thysanoptera): [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 55].

DT Article
TI Inti (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae) a peculiar new genus from tropical
   America.
AU Hansson, Christer (christerdennis@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2729
PS 58-64
PD 23 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2729.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02729p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Inti gen. nov. (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae: Entedoninae), is described from
   Costa Rica and the Dominican Republic, and includes one new species, I.
   levis sp. nov. The new genus is characterized by four autapomorphies,
   and the possession of an additional 14 synapomorphies. Inti is compared
   to the Australian genus Horismenoides Girault with which it shares the
   most apomorphies, indicating a possible sister-group relationship. The
   relationship of Inti to the tribe Euderomphalini and to other groups in
   the subfamily is discussed briefly.
C1 Hansson, Christer; Radmansgatan 13B, Lund, Sweden, Sweden.
EM christerdennis@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   Central America; West Indies
DE Inti levis [Costa Rica /  / New species] [Dominican Republic /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Chalcidoidea, Eulophidae
OR Inti (Eulophidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Entedoninae, Type species Inti
   levis, p. 58]. 
   Inti levis (Eulophidae): [Sp nov, Costa Rica, P. 59].

DT Article
TI A new genus and species from southwestern China in the Frankliniella
   genus-group (Thysanoptera: Thripidae).
AU Zhang, Hongrui (hongruizh@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Mound, Laurence A.
   Xie, Yonghui
SO Zootaxa
VL 2729
PS 65-68
PD 23 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2729.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02729p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new genus and species, Yaobinthrips yangtzei, are described from
   Southwestern China sharing many character states with the
   Austro-Oriental genus Parabaliothrips within the Frankliniella
   genus-group. Within this group the new species is distinguished by the
   presence of tergal craspeda, a pair of uniquely bulbous modified setae
   on the fore tibiae, enlarged fore femora with a basal tooth, and paired
   small pore plates on sternum VI of females.

PT J
AN ZOOR14707049820
DT Article
TI Stratigraphy of the Devonian Kamianama Formation in the Kuzuryu Lake-Ise
   River area, Fukui Prefecture and Its Favositid Coral Fauna.
AU Niko, Shuji (niko@hiroshima-u.ac.jp) 
   Senzai, Yoshihito
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series C Geology &
   Paleontology
VL 36
PS 31-59
PD December 22 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Kamianama Formation in the Kuzuryu Lake-Ise River area of Fukui
   Prefecture, Central Japan is lithologically subdivided into the Oisedani
   and Hakubado Members in ascending order. Following our previous paper
   Niko and Senzai (2006) on the auloporid tabulate corals, 17 species of
   favositids are described herein from the formation. They are
   Klaamannipora oborensis sp. nov., Mesofavosites igoi (Kamei, 1955),
   Sapporipora kamitakaraensis Tsukada, 2005, Pachy-favosites katoi Niko,
   2007, Plicatomurus flexuosus (Kamei, 1955), Squameopora takarensis
   (Kamei, 1955), Squameofavosites fukujensis (Kamei, 1955), S.
   ichinotanensis (Kamei, 1955), S. sugiyamai (Kamei, 1955), Isurugiopora
   obesa Niko, 2005, I. ishiokai sp. nov., Striatopora takayamaensis Niko,
   2005, Thamnopora hayasakai Niko, 2005, Thamnoptychia mana sp. nov.,
   Parastriatopora innae Dubatolov, 1963, Alveolites sp. cf. A. maillieuxi
   Lecompte, 1933, and Coenites kameii sp. nov. In the Kamianama tabulate
   coral fauna, the Squameofavosites sugiyamai, Thanznoptychia mana,
   Klaamannipora oborensis, and Isurugiopora obesa assemblages are
   recognized. The Squameofavosites sugiyamai and probably also T mana
   assemblages belong to the Oisedani Member that is correlated with the
   Lochkovian (early Early Devonian) to Emsian (late Early Devonian)
   Takaharagawa Member of the Fukuji Formation in the Fukuji area, Gifu
   Prefecture. The Hakubado Member contains the K. oborensis and I. obesa
   assemblages, and is correlative with the Emsian to probably Eifelian
   (early Middle Devonian) Ozako Member of the Fukuji Formation.
C1 Niko, Shuji; Hiroshima Univ, Dept Environm Studies, 1-7-1 Kagamiyama,
   Hiroshima, Japan, Japan.
EM niko@hiroshima-u.ac.jp
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1881-9079
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Coenites kameii; Isurugiopora ishiokai; Klaamannipora oborensis;
   Thamnoptychia mana [Japan /  / new species] [Devonian /  / ]. 
   Favositidae [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [Japan / Honshu,
   Fukui, Kuzuryu Lake-Ise River area / stratigraphical distribution]
   [Devonian /  / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia, Tabulata
OR Coenites kameii (Tabulata): [Sp nov, Japan, Devonian, P. 54; Fossil]. 
   Favositidae (Tabulata): [Fossil]. 
   Isurugiopora ishiokai (Tabulata): [Sp nov, Japan, Devonian, P. 47;

   Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14702019519
DT Article
TI Insects found in birds' nests from Argentina. Cyanoliseus patagonus
   (Vieillot, 1818) (Aves: Psittacidae), with the description of
   Cyanolicimex patagonicus, gen. n., sp. n., and a key to the genera of
   Haematosiphoninae (Hemiptera: Cimicidae).
AU Di Iorio, Osvaldo (megacyllene@yahoo.com.ar) 
   Turienzo, Paola
   Masello, Juan
   Carpintero, Diego L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2728
PS 1-22
PD 22 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2728.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02728p022.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The Burrowing Parrot, Cyanoliseus patagonus (Vieillot, 1817) (Aves:
   Psittacidae), is one of the most southern Neotropical parrots. They
   require sandstone, limestone, or earth cliffs where they excavate their
   colonial nest-burrows. Adult C. p. patagonus excavate their own
   nest-burrows, most of them about 1.5 m deep.Each burrow is occupied by a
   single pair that lay one clutch of two to five eggs per year, directly
   on the sand of the breeding chamber. The breeding birds abandon the
   place until the start of the next breeding attempt in the following
   year. Burrow nests from Rio Negro province (Argentina) are inhabited by
   two ectoparasitic insects, the flea Hectopsylla narium (Siphonaptera:
   Pulicidae), and Cyanolicimex patagonicus, gen. n., sp. n. (Hemiptera:
   Cimicidae). The Rio Negro province is the southernmost known limit for
   Haematosiphoninae in the Western Hemisphere, and C. patagonicus is the
   third Haematosiphoninae with a Psittacidae bird as host. As the South
   American genera of Haematosiphoninae cannot be separated using the
   available key due to unsatisfactory characters, the proposition of new
   characters for the identification of the four South American genera,
   together with the corresponding modifications to the key, are presented.
C1 Di Iorio, Osvaldo; Entomologia, Departamento de Biodiversidad y Biologia
   Experimental, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, 40 Piso,
   Pabellon II, Ciudad Universitaria C1428EHA, Buenos Aires, Argentina,
   Argentina.
EM megacyllene@yahoo.com.ar
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Entomology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Parasites
   diseases and disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America

   Cimicoidea, Cimicidae, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Psittaciformes,

   Ornithocoris - Pinto 1927 (Cimicidae): [Diagnostic characters, P. 10]. 
   Psitticimex - Usinger 1966 (Cimicidae): [Diagnostic characters, P. 14]. 
   Cyanoliseus patagonus (Psittacidae): [Host].

AN ZOOR14702019520
DT Article
TI New taxa and systematic assignments of Madagascan Aradidae (Hemiptera:
   Heteroptera).
AU Heiss, E. (aradus@aon.at) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2728
PS 23-38
PD 22 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2728.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02728p038.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB In this paper the flat bug genera Jarmilaia Hoberlandt 1957 and
   Bergrothista Kiritshenko 1959, recorded from Madagascar, are revised. As
   both genera share distinct metathoracic scent gland canals, a basic
   character for the classification for the subfamily Mezirinae, these
   genera, to date treated as Carventinae, are transferred to Mezirinae.
   Two new species of Jarmilaia, rabitschi n. sp. and zetteli n. sp., and
   two species of Bergrothista, maculipennis n. sp. and andasibensis n.
   sp., are recognized and described. For Bergrothista mollis (Hoberlandt
   1957) the new genus Parabergrothista n. gen. is erected and a new
   species P. secunda described and also placed in Mezirinae. A new genus
   Neobergrothista n. gen. with the species N. rotundiventris n. sp.
   belongs also to Mezirinae. All taxa are illustrated by colour
   photographs.
C1 Heiss, E.; Tiroler Landesmuseum, Josef Schraffl Strasse 2a, A-6020
   Innsbruck, Austria, Austria.
EM aradus@aon.at
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa
DE Aradidae [Madagascar /  / Distribution; systematics].

DT Article
TI A new genus and species of Syllidae (Annelida Polychaeta) from off the
   coast of Norway with unusual morphological characters and an uncertain
   systematic position.
AU Lucas, Yolanda (yolanda.lucas@uam.es) 
   San Martin, Guillermo
   Sikorski, Andrey
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 123
IS 4
PS 251-257
PD December 21 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB In this paper a description of Acritagasyllis longichaetosus, an
   enigmatic genus and species of Syllidae (Polychaeta), is given The new
   genus is characterized by a lack of palps, eyes, and median antenna,
   having a single pair of tentacular (peristomial) cirri, distinct ventral
   cirri fused all along their length to parapodial lobes, a slender,
   coiled pharynx without trepan but with a pharyngeal tooth, compound
   chaetae with long shafts, distally enlarged and spinose, and long,
   filiform blades, quite similar to those belonging to members of the
   family Phyllodocidae These characters are very unusual and unique among
   syllids Some characters, like the presence of nuchal lappets,
   bayonet-shaped simple chaetae, and perhaps also the fusion of ventral
   cirri to parapodial lobes, bear some resemblance to those of species of
   Autolytinae However, this new polychaete does not fit into this
   subfamily as it possesses ventral cirri, the chaetae are very different,
   and it lacks a trepan in the pharynx, nor can it be placed into any
   other subfamily, being an "incertae sedis" among the genera of Syllidae.
C1 Lucas, Yolanda; Univ Autonoma Madrid, Fac Ciencias, Calle Darwin 2,
   E-28049 Madrid, Spain, Spain.
EM yolanda.lucas@uam.es
RI Lucas, Yolanda/O-1415-2019
SC Zoology
SN 0006-324X

   Atlantic

TI Monotypic no more, a description of a new crayfish of the genus
   Barbicambarus Hobbs, 1969 (Decapoda Cambaridae) from the Tennessee River
   drainage using morphology and molecules.
AU Taylor, Christopher A. (ctaylor@mail.inhs.uiuc.edu) 
   Schuster, Guenter A.
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 123
IS 4
PS 324-334
PD December 21 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 14
AB Recent fieldwork in the Shoal Creek drainage of the Tennessee River
   drainage in Tennessee has uncovered the presence of a new species of
   crayfish in the formerly monotypic genus Barbicambarus The new species
   differs from the type species in possessing a median carina, less dense
   setae on the antennae, a less angular central projection, a spine at the
   dorsodistal margin of the merus of the cheliped, and a high level of
   divergence in the COI gene region Collecting efforts have so far found
   the new taxon at only two locations and it is thought to be rare.

   Sustainabil, 1816 S Oak St, Champaign, IL 61820, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI A new spinose crayfish of the genus Cambarus, subgenus Puncticambarus
   (Decapoda: Cambaridae), from South Carolina.
AU Cooper, John E. (John.Cooper@ncdenr.gov) 
   Pnce, Jennifer E.
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 123
IS 4
PS 335-344
PD December 21 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Cambarus (Puncticambarus) aldermanorum is a new species of crayfish that
   appears to be endemic to the lower Catawba and Saluda river basins in
   the Piedmont Plateau of South Carolina Morphologically, it is most
   similar to C (P) hobbsorum and C (P) hystricosus It differs from both
   species in having a long, narrow, lanceolate rostrum, and in lacking a
   proximomesial tubercle or spine on the ventral surface of the carpus It
   further differs from C (P) hobbsorum in having hepatic spines, in other
   aspects of spination, and in having a broader areola Cambarus (P)
   spicatus of the Broad River basin is another very spinose crayfish that
   bears some resemblances to C (P) aldermanorum, from which it differs in
   having a broader rostrum with a very short acumen that is delineated at
   its base by marginal spines or tubercles, and a much broader, more
   punctate areola.
C1 Cooper, John E.; N Carolina State Museum Nat Sci, Res Lab, 4301 Reedy
   Creek Rd, Raleigh, NC 27607, USA, USA.
EM John.Cooper@ncdenr.gov
SC Zoology
SN 0006-324X

   America; USA

   species].

DT Article
TI Hyporhamphus collettei, a new species of inshore halfbeak
   (Hemiramphidae) endemic to Bermuda, with comments on the biogeography of
   the Hyporhamphus unifasciatus species group.
AU Banford, Heidi M. (hbanford@westga.edu) 
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 123
IS 4
PS 345-358
PD December 21 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new species of halfbeak, Hyporhamphus collettei is described from
   Bermuda Previously it was considered conspecific with the western
   Atlantic H unifasciatus (Ranzani, 1842) When compared to H unifasciatus
   H collettei is a more slender species and has lower meristic counts
   Meristics were significantly different for dorsal-fin rays (usually
   14-15), pectoral-fin rays (usually 10), and total second-arch gill
   rakers (usually 21-23) A number of morphometric ratios aided in
   distinguishing this species from its closest geographic neighbors, H
   meeki from the east coast of the United States and H unifasciatus from
   the Caribbean, and Central and South American coasts When preorbital
   length to orbital diameter is compared, it is usually less than 0 70 in
   H collettei and greater than 0 70 in H meeki Ratio of body depths at
   pectoral- and pelvic-fin origins to standard length usually less than 0
   12 in H collettei, and greater than 0 12 in H unifasciatus Sequence data
   for 800 bp of mtDNA Cyt b gene clearly separate the Bermudan species
   from other species of Hyporhamphus by a minimum genetic distance of 0
   034.
C1 Banford, Heidi M.; Univ W Georgia, Dept Biol, Carrollton, GA 30117, USA,
   USA.
EM hbanford@westga.edu

SN 0006-324X

   Atlantic Ocean

   / ].

DT Article
TI Five new species of predaceous cheyletid mites (Acari: Prostigmata:
   Cheyletidae).
AU Bochkov, Andre V. (andrevbochkov@gmail.com) 
   Otto, Jurgen C.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2727
PS 1-20
PD 21 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2727.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02727p020.pdf
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB Five new species and 1 new genus of predaceous cheyletid mites (Acari:
   Cheyletidae) are described. Oconnoricheylus gen. nov. (type species O.
   speciosus sp. nov.) differs from Alliea in both sexes by the presence of
   4 setae on tibia II and in males by the palpal claws possessing
   elongated projections, an apically slightly serrate eupathidium ul' and
   comb-like eupathidia acm and sul. Oconnoricheylus speciosus sp. nov.
   (from oranges, USA) differs from O. chimaera (Bochkov & Ochoa) comb.
   nov. (transferred from Alliea) by the presence of 2 filiform setae on
   tibia II, the distinct ornamentation of the dorsal shields, and by the
   absence of angles on the leg tarsal claws. Cheletomimus crowei sp. nov.
   (from avocado, New Zealand) differs from C. filipina Corpuz-Raros and C.
   notelaeae Gerson by smooth filiform setae dF of the palpal femur, smooth
   idiosomal setae c2, the presence of setae ps3, setae se located off the
   propodonotal plate, bases of setae e1 located almost at the same level
   with bases of e2, and by the propodonotal shield in the shape of an
   inverted trapezium. Chelache- les thomasi sp. nov. (from oranges,
   Australia) differs from C. stigmaeoides Barilo by the absence of setae
   c4, short and serrate rod-like setae c2 (about 40 long), and by the
   presence of 2 setae on femur III. Chelacheles indra sp. nov. (from
   beetles Sinoxylon crassum, India) differs from C. baiwanganae
   Corpuz-Raros by the absence of setae f1, by setae h1 being slightly
   shorter than other hysteronotal setae. Bak indonesiensis sp. nov. (from
   undetermined beetle, Indonesia) differs from B. elongatus Patxot & Goff
   and B. faini Corpuz-Raros by the presence of 1 seta (l') on genu III,
   the slightly clavate dorsal setae of the idiosoma, setae e1 being
   subequal in shape and sizes to their anterior hysteronotal setae, and by
   the presence of a pair of distinct lateral teeth on the rostral shield.

TI Stigmaeus boshroyehensis sp. nov. (Acari: Stigmaeidae) from eastern
   Iran, with re-description of Stigmaeus pilatus Kuznetzov.
AU Khanjani, Mohammad (mkhanjani@gmail.com) 
   Izadi, Hamzeh
   Fayaz, Bahman Asali
   Raisi, Hosein
   Rostami, Elaheh
   Dogan, Salih
SO Zootaxa
VL 2727
PS 34-44
PD 21 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2727.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02727p044.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Stigmaeus, S. boshroyehensis sp. nov., is
   described and figured based on females. Specimens were collected from
   soil under pistachio trees at Boshroyeh vicinity, south Khorasan
   province, Iran. Also a known species, S. pilatus Kuznetzov, collected
   from soil under plum and apple trees at Maryanaj vicinity, Hamedan
   province, Iran, is re-described. A key to all known Iranian species of
   the genus is provided.
C1 Khanjani, Mohammad; Department of Plant Protection, College of
   Agriculture, Bu Ali-Sina University, Hamaden, Iran, Iran.

DT Article
TI A new tree frog of the genus Rhacophorus (Anura: Rhacophoridae) from
   southern Vietnam.
AU Rowley, Jodi J.L. (Jodi.Rowley@austmus.gov.au) 
   Le, Thi Thuy Duong
   Tran, Thi Anh Dao
   Stuart, Bryan L.
   Hoang, Duc Huy
SO Zootaxa
VL 2727
PS 45-55
PD 21 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2727.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02727p055.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We describe a new species of rhacophorid frog from the Langbian Plateau
   in southern Vietnam. Rhacophorus vampyrus sp. nov. is distinguished from
   its congeners by a combination of: a pale tan to brick red dorsum; white
   throat, chest and belly; black flanks and anterior and posterior surface
   of thighs; grey to black webbing between fingers and toes; reduced
   finger webbing; and pointed projection at tibiotarsal articulation. At
   present, the new species is known from montane ev- ergreen forest
   between 1470-2004 m elevation. Rhacophorus vampyrus sp. nov. is a
   phytotelm breeder, depositing eggs in foam nests in small tree-holes.
C1 Rowley, Jodi J.L.; Australian Museum, 6 College St, Sydney, NSW, 2010,
   Australia, Australia.
EM Jodi.Rowley@austmus.gov.au
RI Rowley, Jodi J. L./F-2466-2012
OI Rowley, Jodi/0000-0002-2011-9143
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Eurasia; Asia
DE Rhacophorus vampyrus [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Rhacophoridae
OR Rhacophorus vampyrus (Rhacophoridae): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 46].

DT Article
TI The Neotropical species of the genus Osorius GUERIN-MENEVILLE, 1829 with
   remarks to the Neotropical Osoriid complex (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae:
   Osoriinae).
AU Irmler, Ulrich (uirmler@ecology.uni-kiel.de) 
SO Beitraege zur Entomologie
VL 60
IS 2
PS 363-426
PD Dec 20 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB As a result of review studies on the Neotropical Osorius complex a key
   to the Neotropical genera of the tribe Osoriini is provided, which
   includes the new genus Antillosorius with 18 described species from the
   West Indies. New records of the two species Ouloglene barberi NOTMAN,
   1925 and Oryssoma schwarzi NOTMAN, 1925 are given. In total, 35 species
   of the genus Osorius are described or redescribed. Eight new species
   have been found in the collections studied. These are: O. verhaaghi, O.
   paganus, O. venezuelanus, O. pusillus, O. ashei, O. tschirnhausi, O.
   guianensis, O. continentalus. The ecology of the species and
   zoogeographic distributions are discussed.
C1 Irmler, Ulrich; Univ Kiel, Inst Okosyst Forsch, Olshausenstr 40, Kiel,
   Germany, Germany.
EM uirmler@ecology.uni-kiel.de
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology

PT J

DT Article
TI Cydia molybdana (CONSTANT, 1884) - a valid species (Lepidoptera:
   Tortricidae: Olethreutinae).
AU Karisch, Timm (timm.karisch@naturkunde.dessau.de) 
   Pinzari, Mario
SO Beitraege zur Entomologie
VL 60
IS 2
PS 463-470
PD Dec 20 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Because of distinct and constant differences in the male and female
   genitalia described in this paper, Cydia molybdana (CONSTANT, 1884)
   star. rev, is removed from the synonymy of Cydia amplana (HUEBNER, (1796
   - 1799)). Whereas C. amplana occurs in large parts of Europe, C
   molybdana is restricted to the coast and hills close to the
   Mediterranean Sea.
C1 Karisch, Timm; Museum Nat Kunde & Vorgeschichte Dessau, Askan Str 32,
   Dessau, Germany, Germany.
EM timm.karisch@naturkunde.dessau.de
SC Zoology
SN 0005-805X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia
DE Cydia amplana; Cydia molybdana [Europe /  / Biology; distribution;
   natural history; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Tortricoidea, Tortricidae
OR Cydia amplana - Huebner 1796 (Tortricidae): [Description, P. 465;
   Removal from synonymy, Cydia molybdana (Constant 1884), p. 463]. 
   Cydia molybdana - (Constant 1884) (Tortricidae): [Description, P. 467;
   Syn nov, Cydia (Kenneliola) sammuti Diakonoff 1986, p. 467; Removal from
   synonymy, With Cydia amplana Huebner 1796, p. 463].

PT J
AN ZOOR14706042776
DT Article
TI Seasonal occurrence and food habit of introduced an alien fish
   Micropercops swinhonis (Odontobutidae) in the middle area of the Umeda
   River, central Honshu, Japan.
AU Arao, Kazuki (arao@kankyokagaku.com) 
   Kanou, Kouki
   Yokoo, Toshihiro
SO Bulletin of the Biogeographical Society of Japan
VL 65
PS 43-49
PD Dec 20 2010
PY 2010
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Seasonal occurrence patterns and food habits of introduced an alien fish
   Micropercops swinhonis (Odontobutidae) were studied in the middle area
   of the Umeda River, Aichi Prefecture, central Japan, from June 2007 to
   July 2008. This fish (n= 99, 14-48 mm in standard length (SL)) were
   caught throughout the sampling period. Smaller individuals (< 20 mm SL)
   occurred in only June and July, and thereafter grew gradually by
   November. The major food items of this fish overall were aquatic insects
   (larvae of Chironominae spp., Baetidae spp. and Psychodidae sp.),
   epibenthic crustacean (Asellus hilgendorfii) and calanoid and cyclopoid
   copepods, being similar to those of indigenous fishes (e.g., Gobiidae
   and Cyprinidae) in inland waters of central Japan. Based on the
   available data from this and other studies, we discussed potential
   impact of this fish in inland waters of Japan and methods in order to
   limit further range expansion.
C1 Arao, Kazuki; Environm Sci Lab Co Ltd, Kita Ku, 152 Wakazuru, Aichi,
   Japan, Japan.
EM arao@kankyokagaku.com
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine
   &Freshwater Biology
SN 0067-8716
BD Nutrition; Ecology; Population dynamics; Population structure; Habitat;
   Freshwater habitat; Lotic water; Zoogeography; Dispersal; Means of
   dispersal; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Micropercops swinhonis [Diet /  / potential impact] [Population dynamics
   / Seasonal occurrence / ] [Age class distribution / Size structure / ]
   [River /  / ] [Introduction /  / ] [Japan / Honshu, Aichi Prefecture,
   Umeda River / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Eleotridae
OR Micropercops swinhonis (Eleotridae).

DT Article
TI Distributional notes on the genus Platynectes Regimbart, 1879, in Laos
   with the description of a new species (Coleoptera: Dytiscidae).
AU Brancucci, Michel (michel.brancucci@unibas.ch) 
   Vongsana, Khosada
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 32
PS 1-6
PD December 20 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of PIatynectes Regimbart, 1879 is described from Laos. It
   is the third species to be recorded from that country. All of the
   following belong to the subgenus Gueorguievtes Vazirani: Platynectes
   major Nilsson, 1998, Platynectes Brancucci, 2008 and the species
   described here, Platynectes nageli sp.nov. STASTNY'S (2003) key is
   modified. Female of P. njai is described for the first time. Further
   distributional notes for the species hitherto known from Laos are given.
C1 Brancucci, Michel; Natural History Museum, Entomology, Augustinergasse
   2, CH-4001 Basel, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM michel.brancucci@unibas.ch
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key;
   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Platynectes [Checklists /  / ] [Laos /  / ] [ /  / Distribution;
   systematics]. 
   Platynectes (Gueorguievtes) nageli [Laos /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Dytiscidae
OR Platynectes - Regimbart 1879 (Dytiscidae): [Key to species, Extended to
   include new species, p. 5]. 
   Platynectes (Gueorguievtes) nageli (Dytiscidae): [Sp nov, Laos, P. 1]. 
   Platynectes (Gueorguievtes) njai - Brancucci 2008 (Dytiscidae): [First
   time described, Female, p. 4].

DT Article
TI A contribution to knowledge of the Cantharidae (Coleoptera, Elateroidea)
   in Ecuador and French Guiana.
AU Constantin, Robert (robert.constantin@aliceadsl.fr) 
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 32
PS 7-29
PD December 20 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nine species from Ecuador are here described as new to science: Silis
   barragani sp.nov. (prov. Canar), S. sanfranciscensis sp.nov. (prov.
   Cotopaxi), Plectonotum macaraense sp.nov. (prov. Loja), P.
   zanjarajunoense sp.nov. (prov. Pastaza), Belotus lojaensis sp.nov.
   (prov. Loja), Macromalthinus schmidli sp.nov. (prov. Zamora-Chinchipe),
   Maronius brancuccii sp.nov. (prov. Loja), M. peckorum sp.nov. (prov.
   Santo Domingo de los Tsachilas) and from French Guiana: Pvgodiscodon
   touroulti sp.nov. The subgenus Sills (subgen. Peltariosilis) Wittmer,
   1952 is raised to generic status. Discodon apicicorne Pic, 1910 is
   transferred to Pygodiscodon Wittmer, 1966. Pygodiscodon obscurum
   Wittmer, 1966 is a synonym of Pygodiscodon apicicorne (Pic, 1910).
   Belotus baeri (Pic, 1906) is recorded for the first time in Ecuador.
   Peltariosilis amapaen.sis Wittmer, 1966, and Maronius brevicornis
   (Fabricius, 1801) are recorded for the first time from French Guiana.
   Peltariosilis guyanensis (Pic, 1910) is recorded for the first time from
   Surinam. A key to separate the species of Peltariosilis and of
   Pygodiscodon is provided, as are illustrations of the habitus, details
   of pronotum and genital characters of males and females of the new
   species.
C1 Constantin, Robert; 103 impasse de la Roquette, F-50000 Saint-Lo,
   France, France.
EM robert.constantin@aliceadsl.fr

   Maronius peckorum; Plectonotum macaraense; Plectonotum zanjarajunoense;
   Silis barragani; Silis sanfranciscensis [Ecuador /  / New species]. 
   Cantharidae [Ecuador /  / Distribution; new record; systematics] [French
   Guiana /  / ]. 
   Maronius brevicollis; Peltariosilis amapaensis [French Guiana /  / New
   record]. 
   Peltariosilis guyanensisf [Surinam /  / New record]. 
   Pygodiscodon touroulti [French Guiana /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Cantharidae
OR Cantharidae (Cantharoidea): [New record]. 
   Belotus baeri (Cantharidae): [New record]. 
   Belotus lojaensis (Cantharidae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 23]. 
   Discodon apicicorne - Pic 1910 (Cantharidae): [Referred to,
   Pygodiscodon, p. 12].

PT J
AN ZOOR14706045723
DT Article
TI The genus Laena Dejean, 1821 (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae) in Afghanistan,
   with description of three new species.
AU Schawaller, Wolfgang (wolfgang.schawaller@smns-bw.de) 
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 32
PS 129-135
PD December 20 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of the genus Laena Dejean, 1821 (Tenebrionidae:
   Lagriinae) from Afghanistan are described (Laena kabakovi sp.nov., Laena
   kunarica sp.nov., Laena waygalica sp.nov.). A species key for all five
   known species from Afghanistan is provided. The genus appears to be
   restricted to the north-eastern regions and is absent from the arid
   central, south and western parts. These species are not conspecific with
   their numerous congeners from adjacent Pakistan (Chitral, Swat, etc.)
C1 Schawaller, Wolfgang; Staatliches Museum fuer Naturkunde, Rosenstein 1,
   D-70191 Stuttgart, Germany, Germany.
EM wolfgang.schawaller@smns-bw.de
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Laena [Afghanistan /  / Key to species] [ /  / Distribution;
   systematics]. 
   Laena kabakovi; Laena kunarica; Laena waygalica [Afghanistan /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Laena - Dejean 1821 (Tenebrionidae): [Key to species, Afghanistan, P.
   134]. 
   Laena kabakovi (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Afghanistan, P. 131]. 
   Laena kunarica (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Afghanistan, P. 131]. 
   Laena waygalica (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Afghanistan, P. 133].

PT J
AN ZOOR14706045726
DT Article
TI Description of 66 new longhorn beetles and two new genera from the
   Oriental region, mainly from Borneo, China, Laos, and Thailand
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
FT Beschreibung von 66 neuen Bockkaefern und zwei neuen Gattungen aus der
   orientalischen Region, vorwiegend aus Borneo, China, Laos und Thailand
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
AU Holzschuh, Carolus
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 32
PS 137-225
PD December 20 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new genera and 66 new species and subspecies are described and
   illustrated from Philippine (1), Borneo (19), Sumatra (1), China (15),
   Vietnam (1) Laos (17), Thailand (7), and Sri Lanka (1). Imbrius imitator
   Holzschuh, 2006 is considered a synonym of lmbrius ephebus Pascoe, 1866,
   Zegriades maculicollis Matsushita, 1933 and Dymasius fulvescens Gahan,
   1894 are transferred to Gibbocerambyx Pic, 1923. Zegriades gracilicornis
   Gressitt, 1951 is transferred to Dymasius Thomson, 1864 and Kurarua
   cuprea Hudepohl, 1992 to Plutonesthes Thomson, 1864. A further
   characters for Euryarthrum rubricolle Holzschuh, 1991 are briefly
   described. Bunothorax Gressitt, 1937 is the younger synonym of
   Falsanoplistes Pic, 1915 and Sternoplistes takasagoensis Kano, 1933 is
   transferred to Falsanoplistes. The lectotype of Atimura punctissima
   Pascoe, 1865 is designated. Sybrocentrura Breuning, 1947 is removed from
   synonymy with Zotalemimon Pic, 1925 and Sybrocentrura obscura Breuning,
   1947 from synonymy with Sydonia ropicoides Gressitt, 1939. Sydonia
   ropicoides Gressitt, 1939 is transferred to Sybrocentrura Breuning,
   1947.

DT Article
TI A revision of the genus Colaspoides Laporte, 1833 (Chrysomelidae,
   Eumolpinae) from Borneo.

PS 227-258

PY 2010
LA English

AB A key to species of the genus Colaspoides in Borneo is given; 22 species
   are described as new for science: Colaspoides sabahensis, C staudingeri,
   C. sarawacensis, C. takizawai, C. pseudomodesta, C. tenuicornis, C.
   submetallica, C. gorbunovi, C. nitidicollis, C. curticornis, C.
   schawalleri, C. riedeli, C. ahmadi, C. rubra, C. sandakana, C. bolmi, C.
   pleuralis, C. cyaneipennis, C. obscuripes, C. viridiventris, C. shuteae
   and C. mirabilis spp.nov. C. fruhstoaferi Jacoby, 1898 is established as
   a new synonym for C. robusta Baly, 1867.

TI A key to Oriental continental species of Smaragdina Chevrolat, 1936
   [1836] (Chrysomelidae, Clytrinae).
AU Medvedev, Lev N. (lev.n.medevedev@mail.ru) 
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 32
PS 259-287
PD December 20 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A key to Oriental continental species of Smaragdina is proposed. A total
   of 11 species are described as new for science: S. thailandica, S.
   divisomima, S. constructifrons (Thailand), S. bezdeki (Laos), S.
   himalayana (Megalaya), S. occidentalis (North India, Pakistan), S.
   pakistanica (Pakistan), S. daklaka, S. tamdaoana (Vietnam), S.
   bisbipunctata (Myanmar), S. malaccana (Malacca). S. maduraiensis Erber
   et L. Medvedev, 1999 is a new synonym of S. flaviventris Bryant, 1934.
   Smaragdina nigroapicalis Lopatin, 2005 is a new synonym of Aetheomorpha
   apicata L. Medvedev, 1988. Taxonomical notes for some of the species are
   given.

PT J
AN ZOOR14706045747
DT Article
TI Species of Monolepta Chevrolat, 1836 from the Arabian Peninsula
   (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae, Galerucinae).
AU Schlich, Christiane
   Wagner, Thomas (thwagner@uni-koblenz.de) 
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 32
PS 307-322
PD December 20 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Arabian species of Monolepta Chevrolat, 1836 are revised. Three
   valid species were previously known from this region: the Arabian
   endemics M. arvensis Bryant, 1957 and M. saudica Medvedev, 1996, and M.
   lepida Reiche et Saulcy, 1858. The last-mentioned occurs northwards to
   Jordan and also on the western side of the Red Sea from Egypt to
   Somalia. Other species recorded from this area are misinterpretations of
   taxa restricted to the continental African fauna, or already transferred
   to other genera, such as Galerudolphia arabica (Medvedev, 1996).
   Monolepta heydeni Joannis, 1866 is a valid species with similar
   distribution to M. lepida, but needs to be transferred to another genus,
   particularly in respect of the characters of its genitalia. One species,
   M. carsteni sp.nov. is newly described here. Redescriptions or
   descriptions are given for all four valid Arabian species of Monolepta,
   including detailed drawings of external patterns and genitalia,
   distribution maps, photographs of the primary types and an
   identification key.
C1 Wagner, Thomas; Universitaet Koblenz-Landau, Institut fuer Integrierte
   Naturwissenschaften-Biologie, Universitaetsstr. 1, D-56070 Koblenz,
   Germany, Germany.
EM thwagner@uni-koblenz.de
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Monolepta [Asia / Arabian Peninsula / Key to species] [ /  /
   Distribution; systematics]. 
   Monolepta carsteni [Saudi Arabia /  / New species] [Yemen /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Chrysomelidae
OR Monolepta - Chevrolat 1836 (Chrysomelidae): [Key to species, Asia,
   Arabian Peninsula, P. 320]. 
   Monolepta arvensis - Bryant 1957 (Chrysomelidae): [Redescription, P.
   313]. 
   Monolepta carsteni (Chrysomelidae): [Sp nov, Yemen, P. 317]. 
   Monolepta heydeni - Joannis 1866 (Chrysomelidae): [Taxonomic position,
   P. 307]. 
   Monolepta lepida - Reiche & Saulcy 1858 (Chrysomelidae): [Redescription,
   P. 310]. 
   Monolepta saudica - Medvedev 1996 (Chrysomelidae): [Redescription, P.
   315]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14706045747
DA 2020-09-17

TI New data on African Eumolpinae from the collections of the
   Naturhistorisches Museum in Basel (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae).
AU Zoia, Stefano (stefano.zoia@chrysomelidae.it) 
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 32
PS 323-341
PD December 20 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The following new taxa are described, mostly based on material preserved
   in the collection of the Naturhistorisches Museum in Basel: Massartia
   sprecherae sp.nov. (Tanzania), Pseudoxanthus snizeki gen. et sp.nov.
   (Republic South Africa), Dermoxanthus brancuccii sp.nov. (Tanzania), D.
   vittatus sp.nov. (Tanzania) and Lucignolo gen.nov. Lucignolo capensis
   (Lefevre, 1890) is comb.nov. for Trichostola capensis Lefevre, 1890. New
   data are given for Dermoxanthus gedyei Bryant, 1958. The importance of
   the female reproductive organs in the systematics of subfamily
   Eumolpinae is briefly discussed.

AN ZOOR14705038516
DT Article
TI [Comments on the genus Sarothroceras Mabille, 1889 (Lepidoptera:
   Noctuidae: Calpinae).]
FT Bemerkungen zur Gattung Sarothroceras Mabille, 1889 (Lepidoptera:
   Noctuidae: Calpinae).
AU Loedl, M. (martin.loedl@nhm-wien.ac.at) 
SO Quadrifina
VL 9
PS 1-10
PD 20 Dezember 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB The type-species of Sarothroceras MABILLE, 1889, S. alluaudi MABILLE,
   1889 is redescribed and its holotype illustrated for the first time,
   externally as well as the male genitalia. The synonymy to the senior
   synonym S. banaka (PLOTZ, 1880) [Dichromia ?I is confirmed. New junior
   synonyms are published: Phaegorista pallida DRUCE, 1883 syn.n. and
   Sarothroceras sordidus ROTHSCHILD, 1896 syn.n. Due to its tympanum and
   the morphology of the retinaculum the genus still remains in the
   subfamily Calpinae (=Ophiderinae).
C1 Loedl, M.; Naturhistorisches Museum Wien, Burgring 7, A-1010 Wien,
   Austria, Austria.
EM martin.loedl@nhm-wien.ac.at
SC Zoology
SN 1028-6764
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans

   Noctuoidea, Arctiidae, Noctuidae
OR Sarothroceras - Mabille 1889 (Noctuidae): [Taxonomic position, Placement
   in Calpinae, p. 8]. 
   Sarothroceras alluaudi - Mabille 1889 (Noctuidae): [Redescription,
   Holotype, p. 3; First time figured, Holotype, p. 3]. 
   Sarothroceras banaka - (Ploetz 1880) (Noctuidae): [Syn nov, Phaegorista
   pallida Druce 1883, p. 6; Syn nov, Sarothroceras sordidus Rothschild in
   Rothschild & Jordan 1896, p. 6].

DT Article
TI Notes on the genus Tajuria Moore, 1881, from the Sulawesi Region,
   Indonesia, with description of a new subspecies of T. cyrillus Hewitson,
   1865 (Lepidoptera, Lycaenidae).
AU Tennent, W. John
   Rawlins, Andrew
SO Butterflies (Teinopalpus)
VL 56
PS 9-11
PD December 20 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Previously unreported occurrence of Tajuria eyrillus Hewitson, 1865; T.
   iapyx Hewitson, 1865, and T. mantra Felder & Felder, 1860, on islands in
   the Sulawesi Region, Indonesia, are recorded. A new race of T. eyrillus
   from Taliabu and Peleng is described, and references in the literature
   to an undescribed species of Tajuria on Sulawesi are shown to refer to T
   eyrillus. The reported presence of distinct races of T. iapyx on the
   Sula islands is briefly discussed.
C1 Tennent, W. John; Department of Entomology, The Natural History Museum,
   London SW7 5BD, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
SC Zoology
SN 1883-4337
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia

   record; systematics]. 
   Tajuria cyrillus roberti [Indonesia /  / New subspecies]. 
   Tajuria mantra [Indonesia / Sulawesi Region / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Lycaenidae

   Tajuria cyrillus roberti (Lycaenidae): [Subsp nov, Indonesia, P. 9].

   Tajuria mantra (Lycaenidae): [New record].

DT Article
TI Two new taxa of the genus Faunis Hubner, 1819 (Lepidoptera, Nymphalidae,
   Amathusiinae) from the Vietnamese Central Highlands.
AU Monastyrskii, Alexander L.
   Saito, Kotaro
   Uemura, Yoshinobu
SO Butterflies (Teinopalpus)
VL 56
PS 26-33
PD December 20 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Faunis bicoloratus (Nymphalidae, Amathisiinae) was
   discovered in isolated Kon Turn and Da Lat plateaus (Central Vietnam).
   The new species bears some distinctive external characters and the
   female genitalia differed from those in F. canens, inhabiting adjacent
   areas in Northern and northern part of Central Vietnam. The male
   genitalia of both species reveal high similarity. Ranges of the new
   species and F. canens not overlapped. The new species is supposed as the
   result of allopatric speciation.
C1 Monastyrskii, Alexander L.; Vietnam-Russia Tropical Center, 1 Nguyen Van
   Huyen Road, Nghia Do, Cau Giay, Hanoi, Vietnam, Vietnam.
SC Zoology
SN 1883-4337
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia

   Faunis bicoloratus obscurus [Vietnam /  / New subspecies]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Nymphalidae
OR Faunis bicoloratus (Nymphalidae): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 28]. 
   Faunis bicoloratus obscurus (Nymphalidae): [Subsp nov, Vietnam, P. 30]. 
   Faunis canens arcesilas - Stichel 1933 (Nymphalidae): [Systematics, P.
   26].

DT Article
TI Pseudotoothed birds (Aves, Odontopterygiformes) from the Early Tertiary
   of Morocco.
AU Bourdon, Estelle (ebourdon@amnh.org) 
   Amaghzaz, Mbarek
   Bouya, Baadi
SO American Museum Novitates
VL 3704
PS 1-70
PD December 20 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB We describe here new specimens of pseudotoothed birds
   (Odontopterygiformes) from the Upper Paleocene and Lower Eocene of the
   Ouled Abdoun Basin, Morocco. hese Lower Paleogene fossils are among the
   oldest representatives of the Odontopterygiformes and include
   braincases, beak fragments, and long bones. Dasornis toliapica (Owen,
   1873) (2[long dash]3 m wingspan) and Dasornis emuinus (Bowerbank, 1854)
   (3.5[long dash]4.5 m wingspan) were initially described from the Lower
   Eocene London Clay of Sheppey, England. he new species Dasornis abdoun
   (1.5[long dash]1.7 m wingspan) constitutes the smallest species of
   pseudotoothed bird ever discovered. We partly revise the oversplit
   taxonomy of the odontopterygiforms: the two species from the Paleogene
   of England and Morocco are regarded as congeneric, the name Dasornis
   having priority over the name Odontopteryx. We also synonymize
   Neptuniavis minor Harrison and Walker, 1977, and Macrodontopteryx oweni
   Harrison and Walker, 1976, with D. toliapica (Owen, 1873). Moreover, the
   genera Pelagornis Lartet, 1857, and Osteodontornis Howard, 1957, are
   regarded as pertaining to one single taxonomic entity that corresponds
   to the Pelagornis morphotype. In Dasornis, the morphological
   peculiarities of the humerus that are related to gliding light are less
   pronounced than in Pelagornis. he latter taxon includes exceedingly
   specialized gliders that were most likely unable of sustained lapping
   light and relied almost entirely on winds to provide lit. Pseudotoothed
   birds pertaining to the Dasornis morphotype were more generalists and
   could probably undertake lapping light, even if limited. he species of
   Dasornis were soaring pelagic feeders that could disperse over large
   territories like extant albatrosses. hey formed large breeding colonies
   near the shore of the northeastern part of the Moroccan phosphate sea,
   some 55 million years ago. Our work provides evidence that Dasornis was
   widespread in the early Tertiary, as it is currently known from the
   Lower Paleogene deposits of Morocco, England, and Kazakhstan.
   Paleoenvironmen- tal studies show that these marine deposits formed in a
   tropical climate. his could explain the occurrence of both Dasornis and
   prophaethontids in all three Paleogene localities.
C1 Bourdon, Estelle; American Museum of Natural History, Dept of
   Ornithology, Central Park West at 79th St, New York, NY 10024, USA, USA.
EM ebourdon@amnh.org
RI Bourdon, Estelle/B-1115-2011
OI Bourdon, Estelle/0000-0002-5989-1982
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0003-0082; 1937-352X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Ecology; Abiotic factors; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Africa; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Dasornis; Odontopterygiformes [Ecology / Palaeoecology / new record;
   systematics] [Abiotic factors / Palaeoenvironment / ] [Morocco / Ouled
   Abdoun Basin / ] [Eocene / Lower Eocene / ] [Palaeocene / Upper
   Palaeocene / ]. 
   Dasornis abdoun [Morocco /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Pelecaniformes, Procellariiformes,
   Procellariidae
OR Odontopterygiformes - Howard 1957 (Aves): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Dasornis - Owen 1870 (Pelecaniformes): [Emended diagnosis, P. 4; Syn
   nov, Odontopteryx Owen 1873, p. 60; Fossil; New record]. 
   Dasornis abdoun - Bourdon 2010 (Pelecaniformes): [Sp nov, Morocco,
   Eocene, P. 49; Fossil]. 
   Dasornis toliapica - (Owen 1873) (Pelecaniformes): [Emended diagnosis,
   P. 9; Comb nov, Transferred from Odontopteryx, p. 5; Syn nov,
   Macrodontopteryx oweni Harrison & Walker 1976, p. 60; Syn nov,
   Neptuniavis minor Harrison & Walker 1976, p. 60; Fossil]. 
   Odontopteryx toliapica - Owen 1873 (Pelecaniformes): [Referred to,
   Dasornis, p. 5; Fossil].

DT Article
TI [Contribution to the knowledge of Scirtidae.]
FT Zur Kenntnis der Gattung Exochomoscirtes PIC, 1916 (Coleoptera,
   Scirtidae). (153. Beitrag zur Kenntnis der Scirtidae).
AU Klausnitzer, Bernhard (klausnitzer.col@t-online.de) 
SO Beitraege zur Entomologie
VL 60
IS 2
PS 281-293
PD Dec 20 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Exochomoscirtes PIC, 1916 is characterized, and three new
   species are described: E. heinrichdathei n. sp. (Laos), E. holgerdathei
   n. sp. (north-east India) and E. sondaicus n. sp. (Java). The number of
   known Exochomoscirtes is thereby increased to 38.

DT Article
TI On the Lathrobiina of Taiwan (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Paederinae).
AU Assing, Volker (vassing.hann@t-online.de) 
SO Beitraege zur Entomologie
VL 60
IS 2
PS 301-361
PD Dec 20 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Primarily based on material collected by Ale Smetana, Ottawa, in the
   1990s, 29 species of Lathrobiina from Taiwan are described and
   illustrated: Lathrobium alishanum sp. n. (Chiai Hsien: Alishan), L.
   involutum sp. n. (Taichung Hsien: Hsuehshan), L. anmaicum sp. n.
   (Taichung Hsien: Anmashan), L. utriculatum sp. n. (Kaohsiung Hsien:
   Peinantashan), L. extraculum sp. n. (Pingtung Hsien: Peitawushan), L.
   follitum sp. n. (Pingtung Hsien: Peitawushan), L. houhuanicum sp. n.
   (Nantou Hsien: Houhuanshan), L. nenkaoicum sp. n. (Nantou Hsien:
   Nenkaoshan), L. tarokoense sp. n. (Hualien Hsien: Taroko National Park),
   L. alesi sp. n. (Taichung Hsien: Hsuehshan), Platydomene sinuosa sp. n.
   (Ilan Hsien), Lobrathium (Lobrathium) nigripenne sp. n. (Chiai Hsien:
   Alishan), L. (L.) bilobatum sp. n. (Taiwan: widespread), L. (L.)
   extensum sp. n. (Taichung Hsien), L. (L.) bipeniculatum sp. n. (Ilan
   Hsien: Chyr Duan), L. (L.) penicillatum sp. n.(Nantou: Shanlinchi), L.
   (L.) pedes sp. n. (Hualien and Ilan Hsien), L. stimulans sp. n.
   (Kaohsiung: Peinantashan), L. sororium sp. n. (Kaohsiung: Kuanshan), L.
   duplehamatum sp. n.(Nantou Hsien), L. smetanai sp. n. (Kaohsiung:
   Peinantashan), L. furcillatum sp. n. (Pingtung Hsien: Peitawushan), L.
   cornutissimum sp. n.(Kaohsiung: Peinantashan), L. bisagittatum sp. n.
   (Ilan and Taoyuan Hsien), L. digitatum sp. n. (Chiai and Nantou Hsien:
   Yushan), L. bidigitatum sp. n. (Kaohsiung: Peinantashan), L. spoliatum
   sp. n. (Taichung Hsien: Hsuehshan), L. kuanicum sp. n. (Kaohsiung Hsien:
   Kuanshan), and L. coahtum sp. n. (Nantou: Nenkaoshan). Several
   additional Lobrathium species were identified, but remain unnamed, since
   they are represented only by females. Two apparently monophyletic
   species groups are established, the Lathrobium involutum group with ten
   locally endemic species, all of them newly described, and the Lobrathium
   stimulans group including thirteen named species with more or less
   restricted distributions, only one of which was described previously.
   Several species of the L. stimulans group lack the submarginal line of
   the elytra, traditionally one of the key characters separating
   Lobrathium MULSANT & Ray, 1878 from most other lathrobiine genera, but
   evidently secondarily reduced in these species. A key to the Lobrathium
   species of Taiwan is provided. The genus Lobrathium, as well as
   Lobrathium sibynicum ZHENG, 1988 are recorded from Taiwan for the first
   time. The following binomina are established: Lobrathium taiwanense
   (WATANABE, 1998), comb. n. (ex Lathrobium), and Tetartopeus bimaculatus
   (LI, TANG & ZHU, 2007), comb. n. (ex Lobrathium). Additional records -
   the first records since the original description - are reported for
   Lathrobium shaolaiense WATANABE, 1998.
C1 Assing, Volker; Gabelsbergerstr 2, Hannover, Germany, Germany.
EM vassing.hann@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 0005-805X

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Ommatophora Guenee, 1852 with description of four
   new species (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae).
AU Pavesi, F.
   de Vos, R.
   Zilli, A. (alberto.zilli@commune.roma.it) 
SO Quadrifina
VL 9
PS 483-510
PD 20 Dezember 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Revisionary work on the genus Ommatophora GUENEE, 1852 led to the
   discovery of further four species from the Indo-Australian Region, which
   are described here as new: Ommatophora proverai ZILLI, PAVESI & Vos
   sp.n. (Lesser Sunda Islands), O. celebensis ZILLI, PAVESI & Vos sp.n.
   (Sulawesi), O. obliquilinea Vos, PAVESI & ZILLI sp.n. (Sulawesi) and O.
   orientalis Vos, PAVESI & ZILLI sp.n. (Halmahera, NW New Guinea). The
   populations of O. luminosa from Taiwan are distinguished as ssp.
   monotona ZILLI, PAVESI & Vos ssp.n. All species of the genus are very
   similar in habitus, although they can usually be distinguished by small
   differences in pattern, which sharply contrasts with the genitalia
   showing noteworthy differences.

   Italy.

DT Article
TI Catalogue of Blattaria (Insecta) from Argentina.
AU Crespo, Francisco Antonio (fcrespo@anlis.gov.ar) 
   del Carmen Valverde, Alejandra
   Iglesias, Monica Sandra
SO Zootaxa
VL 2726
PS 1-33
PD 20 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2726.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02726p033.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB An updated catalogue is given of the cockroach species recorded in
   Argentina. It includes a list of species, their distribution in the
   different provinces of the country, the institutions in which the type
   specimens are deposited, and an updated list of references. The results
   indicate 87 (plus 2 incertae sedis) species, included in 4 families, 12
   subfamilies and 40 currently recognized genera. A few species are widely
   spread across the country, but 35% (29 + 2 incertae sedis) are only
   known to occur in Argentina. The biotic affinities of the biogeographic
   provinces were studied. The data analysis corresponds with the major
   areas of influence: the Neotropical and Andean regions. A parsimony
   analysis of endemicity (PAE) was performed. The Parana Forest, Pampa and
   Chaco biogeographic provinces are supported by numerous endemic species.
   The families Blaberidae, Blattellidae and Phyllodromiidae include 90% of
   the species. The cockroach fauna from Argentina is still poorly known
   and the number of species undoubtedly is higher. The primary homonym of
   Chorisoneura minuta Rocha e Silva & Aguiar, 1977 was replaced with
   Chorisoneura rochaesilvae nom. n.
C1 Crespo, Francisco Antonio; Departamento Vectores, Administracion
   Nacional de Laboratorios e Institutos de Salud "Dr. Carlos G. Malbran",
   Av. Velez Sarsfield 563 (C1281AFF), Buenos Aires, Argentina, Argentina.
EM fcrespo@anlis.gov.ar
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Land zones; Neotropical region; South America

   [Checklists /  / ] [Argentina /  / ]. 
   Schistopeltis lizeri [Argentina /  / New record].

   replaced by, Chorisoneura rochaesilvae, p. 28]. 
   Chorisoneura rochaesilvae (Blattodea): [Nom nov, For Chorisoneura minuta
   Saussure 1869, p. 28]. 
   Schistopeltis lizeri (Blattodea): [New record].

TI Procladius Skuse from Lake Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, with keys to some
   females and immature stages of the genus (Diptera: Chironomidae).
AU Saether, Ole A. (ole.sather@zmb.uib.no) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2726
PS 34-58
PD 20 Dec 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2726.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02726p058.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Procladius (Holotanypus) rugulosus sp. n. from Lake Winnipeg, Manitoba,
   Canada, is described as male, female and pupa. Six additional species of
   Procladius Skuse are recorded from Lake Winnipeg of which 5 belong to
   the most common species in the lake. The immature stages of P.
   (Psilotanypus) bellus (Loew), P. (Holotanypus) culiciformis (L.), P.
   (H.) denticulatus Sublette, P. (H.) freemani Sublette, and P. (H.)
   sublettei Roback are redescribed. Species keys are given to sufficiently
   known Nearctic females, to pupae of Lake Winnipeg, and to Nearctic
   larvae of Procladius. The distribution of Procladius in Lake Winnipeg is
   mapped and discussed. The separation of larval instars is shown
   approximately to follow Dyar's rule.
C1 Saether, Ole A.; The Natural History Museum, Bergen Museum, University
   of Bergen, N-5007 Bergen, Norway, Norway.
EM ole.sather@zmb.uib.no
