DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Albinaria in Crete (Greece) presence of
   geographically variable monotypic and polytypic species (Gastropoda:
   Clausiliidae).
AU Welter-Schultes, F.W.
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 139
IS 2
PS 143-245
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The highly diverse genus Albinaria in Crete (Greece) is revised in a
   comprehensive study on the morphology and distribution of the species
   Shell character states were transferred to numerical value, to provide a
   base for reproducible results Detailed maps for widespread species based
   on ten thousands of individually measured shells collected at 4850
   localities revealed complex spatial gradients in morphological
   characters, which often varied in various independent directions over
   area Combined colour plots were used to see if spatial variations of
   some genetically independent characters were concordant Only in two
   species (A hippolvti and A corrugata) narrow hybrid zones between
   clearly distinct populations were detected The results suggest that in
   Crete it is possible and useful to apply the concepts fir species and
   subspecies as established by MAYR (1942) and WILSON & BROWN (1953)
   currently used in many other fields of biodiversity research in
   combination with recent knowledge on hybrid zones (BAR-TON S HEWITT
   1985) Together with a new species from Pondikonisi Albinaria pondika n
   sp 31 species containing 7 additional subspecies are recognized in Crete
   and surrounding islands, less than in previous systems in which 37
   species were recognized with more than 40 additional subspecies In the A
   cretensis group only five species (A cretensis A tenuicostata A
   sphakiota A eburnea and A sublamellosa) and no additional subspecies
   were tenable The morphological diversity is best described verbally by
   showing in detail the gradients as they are distributed over area It
   would be inefficient and misleading to correlate the highly complex
   geographical variation in Alhinaria with a sophisticated trinominal
   taxonomic system.
C1 Welter-Schultes, F.W.; Inst Zool, Berliner Str 28, D-37073 Gottingen,

DT Article
TI New information on olenelline trilobites from the Cambrian Sekwi
   Formation in northwestern Canada.
AU Abe, Francine (fabe@ku.edu) 
   Lieberman, Bruce S.
   Pope, Michael C.
   Dilliard, Kelly
SO Canadian Journal of Earth Sciences
VL 47
IS 12
PS 1445-1449
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB A new species of olenelline trilobite, Nevadella keelensis, is described
   from the Early Cambrian (Cambrian Series 2, Stage 3) in the Sekwi
   Formation, Mackenzie Mountains, Canada. The difficulty in discerning
   between Nevadia Walcott, 1910 and Nevadella Raw, 1936 is discussed, and
   a revision of the two genera is suggested, particularly with the
   addition of Nevadella keelensis n. sp. A holmiid trilobite, perhaps
   conspecific with Esmeraldina rowei (Walcott, 1910), was also confirmed
   from the same locality. The E. sp. aff. rowei represents the narrow form
   of a species known for great variability in cephalic form. The trilobite
   material comes from a low diversity, shallow water, peritidal facies
   that was not sampled in previous studies of Cambrian fossils in the
   area, and could prove useful in facilitating biostratigraphic
   correlation across the Selwyn Basin and with other parts of Laurentia as
   well.
C1 Abe, Francine; Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology,
   University of Kansas, 1345 Jayhawk Boulevard, Lawrence, Kansas 66045,
   USA, USA.
EM fabe@ku.edu
RI Pope, Michael/R-4211-2019

PT J
AN ZOOR14704033497
DT Article
TI Eudaemonema webbi sp. nov. (Mammalia, Mixodectidae) from the Late
   Paleocene of western Canada: the youngest mixodectid.
AU Scott, Craig S. (craig.scott@gov.ab.ca) 
SO Canadian Journal of Earth Sciences
VL 47
IS 12
PS 1451-1462
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Mixodectidae (Mammalia, Archonta) are an unusual, poorly known family of
   dermopteran-like mammals that have been discovered at several North
   American localities of primarily early Paleocene age. Among the three or
   four recognized mixodectid genera, Eudaemonema Simpson is perhaps one of
   the least understood, being known from only a few localities of late
   Torrejonian and earliest Tiffanian age. This paper reports on a new
   species of Eudaemonema from the late Paleocene of Alberta, Canada, that
   significantly extends the geographic and stratigraphic ranges of the
   genus. Eudaemonema webbi sp. nov. is known from middle and late
   Tiffanian localities in central and south central Alberta, and it
   represents the youngest and northernmost species of Eudaemonema so far
   discovered. E. webbi differs from the genotypic species E. cuspidata in
   being larger and in having a suite of dental characters (e.g.,
   molariform posterior premolars, enlarged molar protocone and hypocone,
   development of a second grinding platform on the lower molars) that
   suggests an increased emphasis on grinding during mastication. E. webbi
   possesses several dental features (e.g., broad, shelf-like molar
   paraconid-paracristid, lingually shifted molar hypoconulid) that
   resemble those of cynocephalids (Mammalia, Dermoptera), with these
   resemblances interpreted herein as convergent. The occurrence of E.
   webbi at Gao Mine extends the stratigraphic range of Eudaemonema into
   the late Tiffanian (Ti5) and represents the youngest known record of
   Mixodectidae.
C1 Scott, Craig S.; Royal Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology, P.O. Box 7500,
   Drumheller, AB T0J 0Y0, Canada, Canada.
EM craig.scott@gov.ab.ca
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0008-4077
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Canada; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Eudaemonema webbi [Alberta /  / new species] [Palaeocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Dermoptera, Mixodectidae
OR Eudaemonema webbi (Mixodectidae): [Sp nov, Alberta, Palaeocene, P. 1453;
   Fossil]. 
DI 10.1139/E10-074
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704033497
DA 2020-09-17

TI New enantiornithine bird (Aves, Ornithothoraces) from the Late
   Cretaceous of NW Argentina.
AU Novas, Fernando Emilio (fernovas@yahoo.com.ar) 
   Agnolin, Federico Lisandro
   Scanferla, Carlos Agustin
SO Comptes Rendus Palevol
VL 9
IS 8
PS 499-503
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB A new enantiornithine bird Intiornis inexpectatus gen et sp nov is
   described here It is based on a partial hind limb found in beds of the
   Upper Cretaceous Las Curtiembres Formation (Campanian) North West
   Argentina The new taxon is referred to the family Avisauridae on the
   basis of its cranially convex third metatarsal Several features suggest
   close relationships between Intiornis and the avisaurid Soroavisaurus
   from the Lecho Formation (Maastrichtian North West Argentina) Intiornis
   was the size of a sparrow thus representing the smallest Enantiornithes
   known from South America The new species shows adaptations for a
   perching mode of life Moreover the hypothesis suggesting that the flying
   pterosaur reptiles decrease in taxonomic diversity clue to competitive
   interaction with birds is discussed The new species shows adaptations
   for a perching mode of life More over the hypothesis suggesting that the
   flying pterosaur reptiles decrease in taxonomic diversity due to
   competitive interaction with birds is discussed (C) 2010 Published by
   Elsevier Masson SAS on behalf of I Academie des sciences

TI Disjunctive distribution of the basal genus Aplomerus (Hymenoptera:
   Ichneumonidae: Xoridinae) in East Asia and North America, with a new
   species from Japan.
AU Watanabe, Kyohei (ichneumonidae-k-wat@mail.goo.ne.jp) 
   Matsumoto, Rikio
SO Entomological Science
VL 13
IS 4
PS 375-380
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The first Japanese representative of the predominantly Nearctic genus
   Aplomerus Provancher, A. japonicus sp. nov., is described. This species
   can easily be distinguished from the other species by the black body.
   Morphologically this species resembles A. lineatulus (Say) from eastern
   North America but is separable by the sculpture of the propodeum and
   third metasomal tergite. The discovery of this species demonstrates a
   disjunctive distribution of the genus Aplomerus in East Asia and North
   America. Notes on habitat and adult behavior are also given.

DT Article
TI A special encounter with Pseudeustrotia candidula (Lepidoptera
   Noctuidae), a new moth to the Dutch fauna.
FT Een bijzondere ontmoeting met de glanzende marmeruil, Pseudeustrotia
   candidula (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae), nieuw voor de fauna in Nederland.
AU Kraaijeveld, Ken
   Schaffers, Joop (joopschaffers@planet.nl) 
   Jol, Cornellie
SO Entomologische Berichten (Amsterdam)
VL 70
IS 6
PS 178-182
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA Dutch
U1 0
U2 0
AB In 2009 the moth Pseudeustrotia candidula was found at three sites in
   the Netherlands At one site in spring a dead specimen was found in a
   light trap, at the other two sites in autumn a live male was seen, one
   in a light trap and one in the wild The status of the record of the dead
   specimen is unclear This Eurasiatic species is widespread in Europe, but
   is absent in the north-west of Europe and the Iberian Peninsula The
   distribution of this species is subject to fluctuations, among other
   things due to the sensitivity to climate changes During the last two
   decades an extension of its distribution was observed, possibly
   associated with climate warming Little is known about the biology of the
   species The species has two generations per year and probably prefers
   warm, dry habitats, but also frequents more humid places It is found in
   open areas such as meadows, ruderal grounds, forest clearings and
   gardens The foodplants are stated to be grasses, sheep sorrel (Rumex
   acetosella) and branched bur reed (Sparganium erectum) The moths fly
   during the day, but are also active at night They visit flowers and are
   attracted by light Remarkable is the finding of a male in The
   Netherlands in 2009 among 138 other moths in a vegetation of
   dog's-tooth-grass This group of moths among which were a lot of migrants
   was feeding on honeydew, sticking at the ears of dog s tooth grass The
   cause of the presence of the honeydew was the fungus Claviceps sp The
   fungus parasitizes on the inflorescences of grasses, sedges and rushes
   It infects the ovaries of the flowers At a certain stage of infection
   the fungus excretes a sugary liquid, a mixture of plant sap and spores
   This liquid accumulates and forms drops on the inflorescences Flies and
   moths are attracted to the honeydew, feed on it and disseminate the
   spores Analysis of weather conditions makes it plausible that the
   specimens of P candidula found in September in The Netherlands were from
   the north of France. The finding of another specimen in the same penod
   in Belgium strengthens this scenano.
C1 Schaffers, Joop; Dalweg 88, Doorwerth, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM joopschaffers@planet.nl
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8827
BD Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Pseudeustrotia candidula [Netherlands /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Noctuoidea, Noctuidae
OR Pseudeustrotia candidula (Noctuidae): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704028827
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14704032603
DT Article
TI A New Species of Trichodina (Ciliophora: Trichodinidae) from Misgurnus
   anguillicaudatus in China.
AU Hu, Yinheng (huyhen@163.com) 
SO European Journal of Scientific Research
VL 48
IS 2
PS 300-304
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A species of Trichodina Ehrenberg, 1838, collected from gills of the
   freshwater fish Misgurnus anguillicaudatus at Luzhou in China, is
   described. This ciliate is characterized by small body and well
   developed denticles, especially its spacious rays. Descriptions
   presented here were obtained by examinations of specimens prepared using
   the dry silver nitrate impregnation. The described trichodinid resembles
   T. jiroveci and T. sinonovaculae, but it is differentiated from them by
   the shape of denticle and some other measurements. A new Trichodina
   species is erected, and named Trichodina latispina sp. n.
C1 Hu, Yinheng; Luzhou Vocational and Technical College, Luzhou 646005,
   Sichuan, China, China.
EM huyhen@163.com

   disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia; China

   New parasite species] [Sichuan /  / New protozoan parasite species]. 
   Trichodina latispina [Piscean hosts / Misgurnus anguillicaudatus / New
   parasite species] [Sichuan /  / New species from piscean host].

PS 1-8

AB New subfamily Uralopriscinae Aristov et Storozhenko, subfam. n. of
   family Lemmatophoridae is described. Review of the type genus
   Uraloprisca Aristov, 2009 is given. Neotype of Paraprisca uralica
   Zalessky, 1952 is designated. New synonymy is proposed: Uraloprisca
   uralica (Zalessky, 1952) = Paraprisca causaria Novokschonov, 2000, syn.
   n.

DT Article
TI FRUIT FLIES (DIPTERA: TEPHRITIDAE) FROM MALAYSIA AND BRUNEI DARUSSALAM:
   NEW SPECIES AND RECORDS.
AU Chua, T.H. (chuath@gmail.com) 
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 93
IS 4
PS 483-488
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Bactrocera (Zeugodacus) fraserensis, new species, a Dacinae fruit fly
   from Peninsular Malaysia is described and illustrated. It closely
   resembles Bactrocera (Zeugodacus) atrifacies Perkins, Bactrocera
   (Zeugodacus) scutellaris (Bezzi) and Bactrocera (Zeugodacus) scutellata
   (Hendel). The differences between these species are given. New records
   from Peninsular Malaysia are Acanthonevra hemileina Hering, Acanthonevra
   shinonagai Hardy, Phaeospilodes fenestella (Coquillett), Sphenella
   sinensis Schiner and Trupanea glauca (Thomson). New records from East
   Malaysia are Calloptera asteria (Hendel), Dacus (Callantra) ooii Drew &
   Hancock, and Dacus (Callantra) vijaysegarani Drew & Hancock, while those
   from Brunei Darussalam are Carpophthorella sookae Chua and Euphranta
   sabahensis Hancock & Drew.

AB Two new species: Loboscelidia levigata sp. nov. and Loboscelidia
   striolata sp. nov. from China are described and illustrated. A key to
   the Chinese species is provided. Specimens are deposited in the
   Hymenoptera Collection of South China Agricultural University, Guangzhou
   (SCAU). In addition, L. sinensis and L. guangxiensis are redescribed
   from material collected with L. levigata and L. striolata.

DT Article
TI NEW PARASITOID (HYMENOPTERA) RECORDS FOR BAMBOO-SHOOT FLIES
   (TEPHRITIDAE: PHYTALMIINAE AND DACINAE).
AU Dohm, Patrick
   Wharton, Robert
   Kovac, Damir
   Guillen, Larissa
   Freidberg, Amnon
   Rull, Juan
   Aluja, Martin (martin.aluja@ecologia.edu.mx) 
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 93
IS 4
PS 541-545
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB We provide new records of parasitoids (Hymenoptera) attacking bamboo fly
   (Tephritidae: Phytalmiinae, Dacinae) larvae in Malaysia. At least 7
   parasitoid species from 4 families emerged from bamboo fly puparia. Most
   parasitoids were recovered from larvae that had bred in live shoots,
   although some stemmed from larvae that had developed in dead culms.
   Parasitoid developmental times ranged between 7 and 19 d. The braconid
   parasitoids of bamboo-infesting tephritids belong to the Alysiinae
   (Phaenocarpa Foerster) and Opiinae (Fopius Wharton, Psyttalia Walker).
   Hosts for some species have not been recorded previously We also reared
   the alysiine Heratemis filosa Walker from puparia of cyclorrhaphous
   Diptera infesting bamboo shoots that had been attacked previously by the
   weevil Cyrtotrachelus sp.
C1 Aluja, Martin; Instituto de Ecologia, A.C., Km 2.5 Carretera Antigua a
   Coatepec No. 351, Congregacion El Haya, C.P. 91070 Xalapa, Veracruz,
   Mexico, Mexico.
EM martin.aluja@ecologia.edu.mx
RI Aluja, Martin/Q-6810-2018
OI Aluja, Martin/0000-0002-2936-3011

TI GENUS PROMALACTIS (LEPIDOPTERA: OECOPHORIDAE) FROM NORTHERN VIETNAM,
   PART 1: DESCRIPTIONS OF FIVE NEW SPECIES.
AU Kim, Sora
   Park, Kyu-Tek
   Byun, Bong-Kyu
   Lee, Seunghwan (seung@snu.ac.kr) 
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 93
IS 4
PS 546-557
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB This paper is the first of a series treating the genus Promalactis
   (Lepidoptera, Oecophoridae) of Northern Vietnam, and 5 new species are
   described based on material mainly collected in the northern part of
   Vietnam since 2002. The new species are Promalactis albisquama sp. nov.,
   P. griselocula sp. nov., P. heppneri sp. nov., P. rectifascia sp. nov.,
   and P. vittapenna sp. nov. Adults, heads, wing venations, and the male
   or female genitalia of the new species are illustrated.

DT Article
TI PTINUS HISPANIOLAENSIS, A NEW SPECIES OF SPIDER BEETLE (COLEOPTERA:
   PTINIDAE) FROM HISPANIOLA.
AU Philips, T. Keith
   Smiley, Michelle E.
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 93
IS 4
PS 567-570
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species of Ptinus, collected in the Dominican Republic, is
   described and compared to the known West Indian fauna. The species is
   distinguished by the pronotum with 2 lateral spines and dorsally with 2
   loose setal tufts medially on rounded protuberances, and an ely-tral
   setal pattern approximately in a triangular or heart-shaped outline. A
   checklist of the known West Indies Ptinidae (excluding the Anobiidae) is
   given.

   Bowling Green, KY, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF PYRAMICA (HYMENOPTERA: FORMICIDAE) FROM MISSISSIPPI,
   USA.
AU MacGown, Joe A.
   Hill, JoVonn G.
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 93
IS 4
PS 571-576
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of Dacetine ant, Pyramica subnuda new species, is
   described from Mississippi. The new species, known only from a single
   dealate queen, differs from most North American species of Pyramica in
   that it lacks spongiform tissue beneath the petiole and gaster and only
   has a reduced amount of spongiform tissue below the postpetiole. This
   species is provisionally placed in the schultzi group based on
   similarities of mandibular dentition, lack of spongiform tissue on the
   petiole, and other characters that define the group. Additionally, 6 new
   state records of ants in the genus Pyramica are reported for
   Mississippi: Pyramica abdita (Wesson and Wesson), R filirrhina (Brown),
   R inopina (Deyrup and Cover), P margaritae (Forel), R pergandei (Emery),
   and R wrayi (Brown).
C1 MacGown, Joe A.; Mississippi State Univ, Mississippi Entomol Museum, Box
   9775, Mississippi State, MS, USA, USA.
SC Zoology
SN 0015-4040
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA
DE Pyramica abdita; Pyramica filirrhina; Pyramica inopina; Pyramica
   margaritae; Pyramica pergandei; Pyramica wrayi [Mississippi /  / New
   record]. 
   Pyramica subnuda [Mississippi /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Formicoidea, Formicidae
OR Pyramica abdita (Formicidae): [New record]. 
   Pyramica filirrhina (Formicidae): [New record]. 
   Pyramica inopina (Formicidae): [New record]. 
   Pyramica margaritae (Formicidae): [New record]. 
   Pyramica pergandei (Formicidae): [New record]. 
   Pyramica subnuda (Formicidae): [Sp nov, Mississippi, P. 572]. 
   Pyramica wrayi (Formicidae): [New record].

TI Redescription of Strombus labiosus Wood, 1828 (Gastropoda: Strombidae)
   with description of a new species.
AU Dekkers, Aart M. (aart.dekkers@wxs.nl) 
   Liverani, Virgilio
SO Gloria Maris
VL 49
IS 5-6
PS 107-119
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB It is argued that the nominal taxon Strombus labiosus Wood, 1828 is a
   complex of at least two and possibly three species. Strombus labiosus,
   at present attributed to the genus Dolomena, is redescribed. Dolomena
   abbotti sp. nov. is described as new to science and thoroughly compared
   with Dolomena labiosa (Wood, 1828). The new species is mainly known from
   Thailand, the Philippines, Borneo and other parts of the East Indies.
   The holotype of Dolomena labiosa (Wood, 1828) is figured.
C1 Dekkers, Aart M.; Koewijzend 12B, 1695 CG Blokker, Netherlands,
   Netherlands.

SC Zoology

   Ocean; Pacific Ocean

   Sinocyclocheilus mashanensis - Wu, Liao & Li 2010 (Cyprinidae): [Sp nov,
   Guangxi Zhuang, P. 116].

PT J
AN ZOOR14704029408
DT Article
TI Helminths of the brown rat (Rattus norvegicus) (Berkenhout, 1769) in the
   city of Palermo, Italy.
AU Milazzo, C. (c.milazzo@unical.it) 
   Ribas, A.
   Casanova, J.C.
   Cagnin, M.
   Geraci, F.
   Di Bella, C.
SO Helminthologia (Bratislava)
VL 47
IS 4
PS 238-240
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 14
AB A helminthological survey was performed on 143 brown rats (Rattus
   norvegicus) from the city of Palermo (Italy). The overall prevalence of
   helminth infection was 98.60 %. The following parasites were found:
   Brachylaima sp. (prevalence 8.39 %) (Trematoda); Taenia taeniaeformis
   larvae (11.89 %), Rodentolepis nana (13.29 %), Hymenolepis diminuta
   (24.48 %) (Cestoda); Gongylonema sp., (4.90 %), Syphacia muris (8.39 %),
   Nippostrongylus brasiliensis (18.88 %), Eucoleus gastricus (30.07 %),
   Mastophorus muris (30.77 %), Capillaria hepatica (54.55 %), Heterakis
   spumosa (82.52 %) (Nematoda) and one acanthocephalan (0.70 %). The
   species found in males were also present in females, with the exception
   of the acanthocephalan. No significant differences were found between
   males and females in prevalence (P%) or mean infection intensity (MI).
   However, a significant correlation between both P% and MI, as well as
   host age, was observed in some helminth species. Hosts were infected by
   one to six helminth species (median = 3). This is the first report from
   Sicily of helminths in R. norvegicus.
C1 Milazzo, C.; Univ Calabria, Dept Ecol, Via P Bucci S-N, Cosenza, Italy,
   Italy.
EM c.milazzo@unical.it
RI Di Bella, Calogero/J-4924-2016

PT J
AN ZOOR14704029410
DT Article
TI Helminth fauna of two cyprinid fish (Campostoma ornatum and Codoma
   ornata) from the upper Piaxtla River, Northwestern Mexico.
AU Aguilar-Aguilar, R. (raguilar@ibiologia.unam.mx) 
   Rosas-Valdez, R.
   Martinez-Aquino, A.
   Perez-Rodriguez, R.
   Dominguez-Dominguez, O.
   Perez-Ponce De Leon, G.
SO Helminthologia (Bratislava)
VL 47
IS 4
PS 251-256
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB The helminth parasite fauna of 2 species of freshwater fishes from the
   upper Piaxtla River in northwestern Mexico was studied. A total of 41
   cyprinids, corresponding to 20 Campostoma ornatum and 21 Codoma ornata
   were analyzed. Six species of platyhelminths were recorded, including 2
   species of monogeneans (Gyrodactylus sp. and Dactylogyrus sp.), 3
   species of digeneans (Posthodiplostomum minimum, Clinostomum
   complanatum, and Margotrema sp.), and 1 species of tapeworm
   (Bothriocephalus acheilognathi). Helminth parasite infracommunities were
   depauperate, showed low richness and diversity values, and were
   dominated by 1 or 2 helminth species. This pattern is consistent with
   that observed for the helminth parasite communities in other freshwater
   fishes in central and northern Mexico.
C1 Aguilar-Aguilar, R.; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Fac Ciencias, Apartado

DT Article
TI TAXONOMIC STATUS OF CHIRONIUS MULTIVENTRIS AND CHIRONIUS COCHRANAE
   (SERPENTES).
AU Klaczko, Julia
   Machado, Fabio De Andrade
   Scrocchi, Gustavo
   Zaher, Hussam (hzaher@usp.br) 
SO Herpetologica
VL 66
IS 4
PS 476-484
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Recently four subspecies of Chironius multiventris were recognized as
   valid distinct species: C. in. foveatus, C. in. multiventris, C. in.
   cochranae, and C. m. septentrionalis. Although C. foveatus and C.
   septentrionalis clearly deserve specific status, a re-evaluation of the
   characters pointed in the literature as diagnostic of C. multiventris
   and C. cochranae does not support their recognition as valid distinct
   taxa. Additionally, our analysis of the scutellation pattern, continuous
   characters, and hemipenial morphology of 34 specimens, and of the
   available data in literature, shows that there are no significant
   differences between them. We therefore suggest that C. cochranae should
   be synonymized with C. multiventris.
C1 Zaher, Hussam; Univ Sao Paulo, Museu Zool, Ave Nazare 481, Sao Paulo,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM hzaher@usp.br
RI Klaczko, Julia/N-4115-2019; Zaher, Hussam/D-4000-2012
OI Klaczko, Julia/0000-0002-9215-380X; Zaher, Hussam/0000-0002-6994-489X;
   Machado, Fabio/0000-0002-0215-9926
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Reproductive Biology
SN 0018-0831

   Integumentary derivatives; Reproduction; Reproductive system
DE Chironius cochranae; Chironius multiventris [General morphology /
   External morphology / comparative study; taxonomic implications] [Scales
   / Scutellation pattern / ] [Hemipenis / Hemipenis morphology / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14704027742
DT Article
TI The Genera and Species of Tarsiidae.
AU Groves, Colin (colin.groves@anu.edu.au) 
   Shekelle, Myron
SO International Journal of Primatology
VL 31
IS 6
PS 1071-1082
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 3
U2 71
AB We revise the taxonomy of the primate family Tarsiidae. We classify
   extant tarsiers in 3 genera-Tarsius, Cephalopachus, and Carlito-each of
   which originated in the Miocene, or earlier, and each of which is
   allopatrically distributed within a distinct biogeographic region:
   Sulawesi, Sundaland, and Greater Mindanao, respectively. Within the
   genus Tarsius, formerly regarded as a single species, Tarsius spectrum,
   we recognize 8 allopatric and parapatric species, 9 if the inclusion of
   pumilus is warranted, and note that more are likely to be described in
   the near future. We restrict Tarsius tarsier, the senior taxon of the
   genus, to the island of Selayar, off the tip of the southwestern
   peninsula of Sulawesi. In doing so, it is required that we resurrect
   Tarsius fuscus Fischer 1804, for the population of tarsiers from the
   southwestern peninsula near the city of Makassar. We note that neither
   Cephalopachus nor Carlito has been the subject of anywhere near as much
   field research as has Tarsius; thus we question if the currently
   accepted [alpha] taxonomy for these genera is based on knowledge or
   ignorance.
C1 Groves, Colin; Australian Natl Univ, Sch Archaeol & Anthropol, GPO Box
   4, Canberra, ACT, Australia, Australia.
EM colin.groves@anu.edu.au
RI Zimmermann, Elke/D-2281-2015
SC Zoology
SN 0164-0291
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Diagnosis;
   Combination; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Tarsius [Philippines /  / Distribution; taxonomic implications]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Primates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Primates, Tarsiidae
OR Tarsiidae (Primates): [Revision, P. 1074; Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 1080]. 
   Carlito (Tarsiidae): [Gen nov, Type species Tarsius strychita, p. 1077].
   
   Carlito syrichta (Tarsiidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from Tarsius, p.
   1078]. 
   Tarsius (Tarsiidae). 
   Tarsius strychita (Tarsiidae): [Designated type species for new genus,
   Carlito, p. 1077]. 
DI 10.1007/s10764-010-9443-1
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704027742
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14704027744
DT Article
TI Tarsius wallacei: A New Tarsier Species from Central Sulawesi Occupies a
   Discontinuous Range.
AU Merker, Stefan (smerker@bio.uni-frankfurt.de) 
   Driller, Christine
   Dahruddin, Hadi
   Wirdateti
   Sinaga, Walberto
   Perwitasari-Farajallah, Dyah
   Shekelle, Myron
SO International Journal of Primatology
VL 31
IS 6
PS 1107-1122
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 27
AB On the basis of distinguishing characteristics of various genetic
   markers, pelage color, tail tuft, and vocalizations, we describe a new
   species of the genus Tarsius Storr 1780. The new taxon Tarsius wallacei
   sp. nov. occupies a disjunct range in Central Sulawesi, Indonesia. The
   two isolated populations differ significantly in body size, but are
   alike in color, tail tuft dimensions, vocalizations, and genetic
   composition. Morphologically, the new species is similar to other
   Sulawesi lowland tarsiers. In the field, it can be distinguished from
   its congeners via a characteristic duet song and its yellow-brown pelage
   coloration and a copper-colored throat. Genetic analyses prove
   Y-chromosomal and mitochondrial DNA sequences and also microsatellite
   allele frequencies to be absolutely diagnostic.
C1 Merker, Stefan; Univ Frankfurt, Dept Ecol & Evolut, Frankfurt, Germany,
   Germany.
EM smerker@bio.uni-frankfurt.de
RI Driller, Christine/AAW-2151-2020

   Stefan/0000-0003-3142-7720

DT Article
TI Description of Bryceella perpusilla n. sp. (Monogononta: Proalidae), a
   New Rotifer Species from Terrestrial Mosses, with Notes on the Ground
   Plan of Bryceella REMANE, 1929.
AU Wilts, Eike F. (eike.f.wilts@mail.uni-oldenburg.de) 
   Arbizu, Pedro Martinez
   Ahlrichs, Wilko H.
SO International Review of Hydrobiology
VL 95
IS 6
PS 471-481
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We here describe the new proalid rotifer species Bryceella perpusilla n.
   sp. on the basis of light and electron microscopy. The species,
   certainly representing one of the smallest rotifer and even metazoan
   species at all, was obtained in January 2008 from terrestrial mosses of
   North-west Germany. Bryceella perpusilla n. sp. is distinguished from
   other species of the genus by the very small size, the slender body
   outline, the short apical styli, the triangular rostrum, the outward
   curving, blunt and rod-shaped toes, the four-nucleated vitellogermarium,
   the slender manubria and the caudally directed alulae. With our
   observations, that can be used for future cladistic analyses of the
   Proalidae, we are able to define the generic diagnosis of Bryceella more
   precisely and to give an adapted species key.
C1 Wilts, Eike F.; Carl von Ossietzky Univ Oldenburg, Dept Biol & Environm
   Sci, Carl von Ossietzky Str 9-11, Oldenburg, Germany, Germany.
EM eike.f.wilts@mail.uni-oldenburg.de
RI Ahlrichs, Wilko H/E-8166-2010
OI Martinez-Arbizu, Pedro/0000-0002-0891-1154
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 1434-2944

   morphology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

   Bryceella perpusilla [Germany /  / New species] [Poland /  / ].

DT Article
TI Determination of the species of Curculionoidea superfamily on alfalfa
   fields (Medicago sativa L.) and their distribution in Bursa Province of
   Turkey.
AU Coskuncu, Kiymet Senan (coskuncu@uludag.edu.tr) 
   Gencer, Nimet Sema
SO Journal of Biological & Environmental Sciences
VL 4
IS 12
PS 123-131
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This study was carried out to determine superfamily species of
   Curculionoidea which is living in the alfalfa areas of Bursa province of
   Turkey during 2004-2005. Insect samplings were collected by sweep net
   over a 7-12 day period, on alfalfa fields. In this study, among
   determined species, Hypera postica (Gyllenhal 1813), Apion pisi
   (Fabricius 1801), Sitona macularius (crinitus) (Marsham 1802), Sitona
   hispidulus (Fabricius 1777) and Sitona humeralis Stephens 1831 were
   recorded as important pests and widespread. The most abundance species
   rates were Apion pisi 85.0%, Hypera postica 7.2%, S. humeralis 3.4%, S.
   macularis 2.1%, S. hispidulus 1.3 % respectively. Nonetheless Sitona
   lineatus (Linneaus 1758), Sitona flavescens (Marshall 1802),
   Ceutorhynchus pallidactylus (Marsham 1802), Ceutorhynchus anatolicus
   Schultze, 1900, Phyllobius sp., Protapion trifolii (Linnaeus 1768),
   Ceratapion gibbirostre (Gyllenhal 1813), Gymnetron rotundicolle
   Gyllenhal 1838 were also found in towns of Bursa province. S.
   flavescens, Ceutorhynchus pallidactylus, C. anatolicus, Protapion
   trifolii, C. gibbirostre were the first record in Bursa province.
C1 Coskuncu, Kiymet Senan; Bursa Province Directorate of Ministry of
   Agriculture and Rural Affairs, 16170 Hurriyet, Bursa, Turkey, Turkey.
EM coskuncu@uludag.edu.tr

BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Ecology; Community structure;
   Habitat; Man made habitat; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia

   pallidactylus; Protapion trifolii; Sitona flavescens [Turkey / Bursa /
   New record]. 
   Curculionoidea [Plant hosts / Medicago sativa / Prevalence] [Species
   diversity /  / ] [Cultivated land habitat / Alfalfa fields / faunal
   list] [Turkey / Bursa / ].

TI A NEW GENUS OF THE SUBFAMILY CUBACUBANINAE (INSECTA: ZYGENTOMA:
   NICOLETIIDAE) FROM CAVES IN SOUTH-CENTRAL AND SOUTHWESTERN USA.
AU Espinasa, Luis (luis.espinasa@marist.edu) 
   Furst, Stephen
   Allen, Thomas
   Slay, Michael E.
SO Journal of Cave and Karst Studies
VL 72
IS 3
PS 161-168
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The genus Speleonycta is erected, and S. ozarkensis, n. sp., is
   described and separated from other species of the subfamily
   Cubacubaninae. The type species was collected from several caves in the
   Ozark Plateau, while two more species, collected from a cave in Arizona
   and from a cave in California, remain under study. Morphology and
   preliminary analyses using histone DNA indicate that the new genus may
   be related to Texoreddellia, another nicoletiid from caves of Texas and
   northern Mexico.

   USA, USA.

TI Two new species of Kudoa Meglitsch (Multivalvulida: Kudoidae) from the
   fishes of Sundarban coast of West Bengal, India.

AB Two new species of Kudoa Meglitsch, 1947 (Multivalvulida, Kudoidae),
   viz., Kudoa kalae sp.n. a quadrate type and Kudoa hoffmani sp.n. a

PT J
AN ZOOR14704031688
DT Article
TI New Endemic Species of Riama (Squamata: Gymnophthalmidae) from Northern
   Colombia.
AU Arredondo, Juan Camilo (jcas36@gmail.com) 
   Sanchez-Pacheco, Santiago J.
SO Journal of Herpetology
VL 44
IS 4
PS 610-617
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new endemic species of gymnophthalmid lizard of the genus Riama is
   described from the Cordillera Occidental of northern Colombia. The new
   species differs from all known Riama by pholidosis, hemipenial
   morphology, and color pattern. The four known endemic Colombian species,
   Riama columbiana, Riama laevis, Riama stellae, and Riama striata, occur
   in different montane forests and are not known to be sympatric with the
   new species. The new species most resembles R. laevis from the
   Cordillera Occidental of the Colombian Andes, but it differs in having
   15 longitudinal scale rows, 21-23 transverse scale rows in males and 22
   in females, and limbs that do not overlap or just touch when adpressed
   against the body.
C1 Arredondo, Juan Camilo; Univ Sao Paulo, Museu Zool, Caixa Postal 42494,
   BR-04218170 Sao Paulo, Brazil, Brazil.
EM jcas36@gmail.com
OI Sanchez-Pacheco, Santiago J./0000-0003-4253-1101
SC Zoology
SN 0022-1511
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Riama afrania [Colombia /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Teiidae
OR Riama afrania (Teiidae): [Sp nov, Colombia, P. 611]. 
DI 10.1670/09-218.1
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704031688
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14704029129
DT Article
TI Topomyia (Suaymyia) kelabitense (Diptera: Culicidae), a new species from
   Sarawak, Malaysia.
AU Katano, Rie
   Miyagi, Ichiro
   Toma, Takako
SO Medical Entomology and Zoology
VL 61
IS 4
PS 353-361
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Topomyia (Suaymyia) kelabitense is described from Bario
   and Ba'Kelalan highlands in Sarawak, Malaysia. The adult male and
   female, pupa and larva are described in detail and illustrations of the
   male genitalia, pupa and larva are provided. This species is easily
   distinguished from all known species of the subgenus Suaymyia by the
   male genitalia and larval characters. The larva is predacious with well
   developed maxillae apparently adapted for grasping prey. Larvae were
   collected from the leaf axils of Daun Itip (Phrynium capitatum), a
   common plant found in mountain forests.
C1 Katano, Rie; Ocean Hlth Corp, Lab Mosquito Systemat SE Asia & Pacific,
   4-21-11 Iso, Okinawa, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology
SN 0424-7086
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Topomyia (Suaymyia) kelabitense [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Culicidae
OR Topomyia (Suaymyia) kelabitense - Miyagi & Toma 2010 (Culicidae): [Sp
   nov, Malaysia, P. 354]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704029129

DT Article
TI Taxonomic notes on Simulium (Montisimulium) laoleense and a closely
   related new species (Diptera: Simuliidae) from Thailand.
AU Takaoka, Hiroyuki
   Srisuka, Wichai
   Saeung, Atiporn
   Otsuka, Yasushi
   Aoki, Chiharu
   Choohote, Wej
SO Medical Entomology and Zoology
VL 61
IS 4
PS 363-374
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The female, male and pupa of Simulium (Montisimulium) laoleense Takaoka
   and Choochote are described for the first time based on adults reared
   from pupae and pupal exuviae collected from Siribhume Waterfall (type
   locality), Chiang Mai, Thailand. The number of the pupal gill filaments
   is corrected as 14 (not 12) on the basis of reexamination of the type
   larval specimens. Simulium (M.) nanense sp. nov., a close ally of S.
   (M.) laoleense, is also described. The morphological and molecular
   differences between the two species are noted.
SC Zoology
SN 0424-7086
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Simulium (Montisimulium) nanense [Thailand /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Simuliidae
OR Simulium (Montisimulium) laoleense - Takaoka & Choochote 2005
   (Simuliidae): [First time described, Female, male & pupa, p. 364]. 
   Simulium (Montisimulium) nanense - Takaoka & Srisuka 2010 (Simuliidae):
   [Sp nov, Thailand, P. 371]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704029130
DA 2020-09-17

U1 0

AB Two new species of flesh flies, Goniophyto kakinumai sp. nov. and G.

DT Article
TI DESCRIPTION OF TWO NEW SPECIES OF DORYLAIMELLUS COBB, 1913 (NEMATODA:
   DORYLAIMIDA) FROM KUMBHALGARH WILDLIFE SANCTUARY, UDAIPUR.
AU Bohra, P.
   Sultana, R.
SO Nematologia Mediterranea
VL 38
IS 2
PS 203-209
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Dorylaimellus Cobb, 1913, collected from
   Kumbhalgarh Wildlife Sanctuary, Udaipur, Rajasthan, India, are described
   and illustrated. Dorylaimellus stylus n. sp. is characterized by L =
   0.42-0.53mm, a = 28.8-35.6, b = 2.4-2.9, c = 22.3-35.2, c' = 1.4-1.7, V
   = 56.2-61.8, cuticularised pieces in lip region, odontophore with
   distinct basal knobs and dorsal arm curved ventrally above basal knob,
   amphidelphic female with symmetrical ovaries, rectum 0.6-0.9 anal body
   diameter long and tail dorsally convex, ventrally straight with rounded
   terminus. Dorylaimellus longus n. sp. is characterized by L = 1.41-1.48
   mm, a = 54.3-59.0, b = 8.0-9.1, c = 36.9-47.1, c' = 1.6-1.9, V =
   49.5-51.5, cuticle with fine transverse and longitudinal lines,
   odontophore with distinct flanges, amphidelphic female with symmetrical
   ovaries, rectum 0.5-0.6 anal body diameter long and tail convex-conoid
   with broadly rounded terminus.
SC Zoology
SN 0391-9749
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Dorylaimellus longus; Dorylaimellus stylus [Rajasthan /  / New species].
   
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Dorylaimellus longus (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Rajasthan, P. 207]. 
   Dorylaimellus stylus (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Rajasthan, P. 203]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704030668

TI EPOPHTHALMIA BANNAENSIS SPEC. NOV., A NEW DRAGONFLY FROM YUNNAN, CHINA
   (ANISOPTERA: CORDULIIDAE).
AU Zha, L.-S.
   Jiang, Y.-H. (Jiangyh26@yahoo.com.cn) 
SO Odonatologica
VL 39
IS 4
PS 363-366
PD Dec 1 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The new sp. is described and illustrated. Holotype [male]: China,
   Yunnan: Xishuang-banna Tropical Botanical Garden (21.55[degree]N,
   101.13[degree]E), 500m, 4-VIII-2004; deposited at the Institute of
   Zoology, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an: China. It is related to
   Epophthalmia frontalis Selys, but is easily separated based on
   structural differences of the secondary and caudal genitalia and slight
   differences in colouration.

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI New data on the Carboniferous corals of the Donets Basin.
AU Ogar, Victor V. (ogar_victor@ukr.net) 
SO Palaeoworld
VL 19
IS 3-4
PS 284-293
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Additional data are given here on the taxonomic diversity and
   distribution of the Carboniferous rugose and tabulate corals of the
   Donets Basin (Ukraine). Keyserlingophyllum obliquum (Keyserling, 1846)
   was recorded in the Tournaisian part of the section for the first time.
   Rotiphyllum omaliusi (Milne-Edwards et Haime, 1851) and Dorlodotia
   pseudovermiculare (McCoy, 1849) were found in Tournaisian-Visean
   boundary deposits. Zaphrentites parallelus (Carruthers, 1910), together
   with Sutherlandia and Cladochonus, was discovered approximately in the
   mid-Visean. The tabulate coral Volnovakhipora n. gen. from the
   Tournaisian and the rugose coral Arctophyllum lugankaensis n. sp. from
   the Gzhelian are established and described. [copyright] 2010 Elsevier
   Ltd and Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, CAS. All rights
   reserved.
C1 Ogar, Victor V.; Kyiv Taras Shevchenko Univ, Dept Geol, 90 Vasilkivska
   Str, Kiev, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM ogar_victor@ukr.net
RI Ohar, Viktor/H-9474-2018
OI Ohar, Viktor/0000-0002-7566-3648
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1871-174X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Arctophyllum lugankaensis; Volnovakhipora insignis [Ukraine /  / new
   species] [Carboniferous /  / ]. 
   Keyserlingophyllum [Ukraine / Donets Basin / new record] [Carboniferous
   / Tournaisian / ]. 
   Rugosa; Tabulata [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [Ukraine / Donets
   Basin / stratigraphical distribution] [Carboniferous / Lower
   Carboniferous / ]. 
   Volnovakhipora [Carboniferous /  / New genus]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia, Rugosa, Tabulata
OR Rugosa (Zoantharia): [Fossil]. 
   Tabulata (Zoantharia): [Fossil]. 
   Arctophyllum lugankaensis (Rugosa): [Sp nov, Ukraine, Carboniferous, P.
   288; Fossil]. 
   Keyserlingophyllum (Rugosa): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Volnovakhipora (Tabulata): [Gen nov, Of family Neoroemeriidae?, Type
   species Volnovakhipora insignis, p. 287, Carboniferous; Fossil]. 
   Volnovakhipora insignis (Tabulata): [Sp nov, Ukraine, Carboniferous, P.

DT Article
TI Fifth report on Symphypleona from Russia, and also a review of
   Deuterosminthurus kaplini Martynova, 1979 from Turkmenistan (Insecta,
   Collembola).
AU Bretfeld, Gerhard (gerhard.bretfeld@kielnet.net) 
SO Soil Organisms
VL 82
IS 3
PS 301-316
PD Dezember 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This study again deals with Collembola Symphypleona from Russia and the
   adjacent countries. Out of 33 slide preparations from Russia remarks
   upon nine already known species are given and two new species are
   described. Also a new genus is proposed for Deuterosminthurus kaplini
   Martynova, 1979; a new genus is suggested for the species with
   characteristics of both the genera Sminthurus Latreille, 1802 sensu
   Betsch & Betsch Pinot 1984 and Spatulosminthurus Betsch & Betsch Pinot,
   1984; and a new key is given to the Sminthurus species of the
   Palaearctic.
C1 Bretfeld, Gerhard; Raiffeisenstr 7B, Felde, Germany, Germany.
EM gerhard.bretfeld@kielnet.net
SC Zoology

DT Article
TI Pedonides alcochetensis n. g. n. sp (Insecta, Collembola,
   Sminthurididae) with two clasping organs from the mainland of Portugal.
AU Bretfeld, Gerhard (gerhard.bretfeld@kielnet.net) 
SO Soil Organisms
VL 82
IS 3
PS 317-323
PD Dezember 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A male of the family Sminthurididae is described, which was found in a
   soil sample from Portugal, near Lisbon. This male not only has clasping
   antennae but the legs 11 are also modified for clasping. Because of this
   uncommon characteristic and of the special shapes of the antennal setae,
   a new genus and a new species are created for this male.
C1 Bretfeld, Gerhard; Raiffeisenstr 7B, Felde, Germany, Germany.
EM gerhard.bretfeld@kielnet.net

   Eurasia; Europe

   Pedonides alcochetensis, p. 317]. 
   Pedonides alcochetensis (Collembola): [Sp nov, Portugal, P. 318].

DT Article
TI Ten new species in genera Hypoaspis (s. lat.) Canestrini, 1884,
   Dendrolaelaps (s. lat.) Halbert, 1915, and Ameroseius Berlese, 1903
   (Acari Gamasina) from Finland.
AU Huhta, Veikko
   Karg, Wolfgang
SO Soil Organisms
VL 82
IS 3
PS 325-349
PD Dezember 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB This paper reports ten new species and one new status of Parasitiformes
   Gamasina, found in Finland. The described species are Hypoaspis
   (Alloparasaus) pratensis n. sp., Hypoaspis (Cosmolaelaps) nuchaeli n.
   sp. Hypoaspis (Pneumolaelaps) saana n. sp. Hypoaspis (Pneumolaelaps)
   collina n. sp., Androlaelaps myrmecophila (Evans & Till, 1966) new
   status, Punctodendrolaelaps formicarius n. sp., Multidendrolaelaps putte
   n. sp, Multidendrolaelaps subcorticalis n. sp., Dendrolaelaps casualty
   n. sp., Ameroseius lehtineni n. sp. and Sinosetus pinnatus n. sp.
   Sinoseius Bai et al, 1995, is accepted as a separate genus, including
   the species S. pinnatus n. sp. and S. lobatus Bai et al, 1995.
   Identification keys are presented to clarify the taxonomic position of
   the new species in relation to the previously known species.

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

PT J
AN ZOOR14704028611
DT Article
TI A new psychodid species from Saban tank bromeliads.
AU Wagner, Ruediger (ruediger.wagner@uni-kassel.de) 
   Richardson, Barbara A.
   Richardson, M.J.
SO Studies on Neotropical Fauna and Environment
VL 45
IS 3
PS 121-127
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of Neotropical Psychodidae, Alepia apexalba sp. nov., is
   described from dry-forest tank bromeliads in Saba, Netherlands Antilles.
   Larvae, pupae and adults are described and figured. It is possible to
   relate larvae and adults because the latter were reared from pupae
   collected from the bromeliads (Tillandsia utriculata) that also
   contained larvae. Bromeliads are adapted to intercept canopy litter and
   throughfall water, and decaying litter is washed into and retained by
   the leaf bases. It is from this aquatic habitat that the larvae and
   pupae were collected.
C1 Wagner, Ruediger; Univ Kassel, FB Nat Sci 10, Kassel, Germany, Germany.
EM ruediger.wagner@uni-kassel.de
OI Richardson, Michael/0000-0003-1232-4793
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0165-0521
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Associations; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies

TI Description of the first South American species of Neocylloepus Brown
   (Coleoptera: Elmidae): N. chaparensis sp nov from Bolivia.
AU Manzo, Veronica (veromanzo@yahoo.com.ar) 
   Moya, N.
SO Studies on Neotropical Fauna and Environment
VL 45
IS 3
PS 129-138
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of riffle beetle from Bolivia, Neocylloepus chaparensis
   sp. nov., is described and illustrated from adults of both sexes and the
   larva. This is the first species of Neocylloepus Brown described from
   South America. The new species is compared with other species described
   in the genus. Distributional records, diagnoses and a key to distinguish
   the species of genus are included.

PT J
AN ZOOR14704028136
DT Article
TI A new species of giant marabou stork (Aves: Ciconiiformes) from the
   Pleistocene of Liang Bua, Flores (Indonesia).
AU Meijer, Hanneke J.M. (MeijerH@naturalis.nl) 
   Due, Rokus Awe
SO Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 160
IS 4
PS 707-724
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Fossils of the genus Leptoptilos from the Pleistocene of Liang Bua,
   Flores, Indonesia, belong to a new species of giant marabou stork,
   Leptoptilos robustus sp. nov. This giant bird, estimated at 1.80 m in
   length, was similar in dimensions to extant Leptoptilos dubius, except
   for the tibiotarsus. The thick cortical bone wall of the tibiotarsus and
   the estimated weight of 16 kg imply a reduced flight capability.
   Osteological and biometric characters suggest that L. robustus is most
   closely related to L. dubius. An evolutionary lineage is proposed in
   which a volant L. dubius- like ancestor in the Middle Pleistocene
   evolved into the Late Pleistocene L. robustus on Flores, with a
   concomitant reduction of the ability to fly and an increase in body
   size. The large body size and terrestrial lifestyle of L. robustus are
   responses to an unbalanced, insular environment with abundant prey items
   and a lack of mammalian carnivores, and emphasize the extraordinary
   nature of the Homo floresiensis fauna.
C1 Meijer, Hanneke J.M.; Natl Nat Hist Museum Nat, POB 9517, Leiden,
   Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM MeijerH@naturalis.nl
RI Meijer, Hanneke J.M./A-1912-2013
OI Meijer, Hanneke J.M./0000-0001-7066-6869
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0024-4082
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary
DE Leptoptilos robustus [Indonesia /  / new species] [Pleistocene /  / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Ciconiiformes, Ciconiidae
OR Leptoptilos robustus (Ciconiidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, Pleistocene, P.
   714; Fossil]. 
DI 10.1111/j.1096-3642.2010.00616.x
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704028136
OA Bronze
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14702009940
DT Article
TI Contribution to the Fauna of Family Phytoseiidae (Acari) from Pakistan.
AU Afzal, Muhammad (chafzal64@yahoo.com) 
   Bashir, Muhammad Hamid
   Raza, Abu Bakar Muhammad
   Kamran, Muhammad
SO Pakistan Journal of Zoology
VL 42
IS 6
PS 719-723
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Mites belonging to the family Phytosciidae are renowned bio-control
   agents for the plant feeding mites and small soft bodied insects. As a
   result of thorough survey of different localities of Pakistan. two new
   species Phytoseius (Phytoseius) pactus and Phytoseius (Phytoseius)
   divert were collected from Changa Manga and Choa Saiden Shah. Holotypes
   were deposited in the Acarology Research Laboratory. Department of Agri.
   Entomology. University of Agriculture, Faisalabad. Specimens were
   mounted on the glass slides with the help of Hoyer's medium and
   identified with the help of phase contrast microscope. These specimens
   were compared with the already described species. Ceremonial
   description, illustration of main body parts, host range and comparison
   remarks are also given.
C1 Afzal, Muhammad; Univ Sargodha, Univ Coll Agr, Sargodha, Pakistan,
   Pakistan.
EM chafzal64@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 0030-9923

   Eurasia; Asia

TI First record of a slave-making ant Myrmoxenus gordiagini Ruzsky, 1902
   (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in Slovenia.
AU Bracko, Gregor (gregor.bracko@bf.uni-lj.si) 
SO Acta Entomologica Slovenica
VL 18
IS 2
PS 137-142
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An active slave-making ant Myrmoxenus gordiagini Ruzsky, 1902 is
   recorded for the first time for Slovenia. The species was found on the
   Tinjan hill near Koper in two Temnothorax host colonies, most probably
   identical to T. lichtensteini sp. 2, in the years 2007 and 2009. This is
   the northernmost record of M. gordiagini in its southeast European part
   of the range.
C1 Bracko, Gregor; University of Ljubljana, Biotechnical Faculty,
   Department of Biology, Vecna pot 111, SI 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia,
   Slovenia.

TI [Reestablishment of the tribe Protonarthrini Thomson, 1864. Diagnosis of
   a new African genus belonging to it and transfer of Protonarthron
   tuberculicolle Breuning, 1950 into the Acmocerini tribe (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).]
FT Rehabilitation de la tribu des Protonarthrini Thomson, 1864. Diagnose
   d'un genre africain nouveau la composant, et transfert dans la tribu des
   Acmocerini de Protonarthron tuberculicolle Breuning, 1950 (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).
AU Teocchi, Pierre
   Sudre, Jerome
   Adlbauer, Karl
   Jiroux, Eric
SO Cahiers Magellanes
SU NS No 2
PS 48-61
PD Decembre 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The tribe of Protonarthrini Thomson, that was unduly attached to the
   tribe of Dorcaschematini, is now rehabilitated. A new species, belonging
   to the genus Brachynarthron Breuning, 1956, is described. Brachynarthron
   allardi Breuning, is considered as a synonym of Falsosophronica
   fuscobrunnea Breuning, 1952. A new genus, of the tribe of
   Protonarthrini, is described. Finally, the taxon Protonarthron
   tuberculicolle Breuning is transfered to the tribe of Acmocerini Thomson
   and in the genus Acridoschema Thomson, when the species Acridoschema
   allardi Teocchi becames synonymous with Acridoschema tuberculicolle
   (Breuning).
C1 Teocchi, Pierre; 210, chemin des bois, la Barthelasse, F84000 Avignon,

DT Article
TI [Revision of Compsocerini Thomson, 1864 from French Guiana (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Cerambycinae).]
FT Revision des Compsocerini Thomson, 1864 de Guyane (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Cerambycinae).
AU Dalens, Pierre-Henri (ph.dalens@laposte.net) 
   Tavakilian, Gerard Luc
   Touroult, Julien
SO Cahiers Magellanes
SU NS No 2
PS 79-111
PD Decembre 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Five new species of Compsocerini are described: Aglaoschema camusi n.
   sp., A. vinolenta n. sp., A. quieci n. sp., A. geoffroyi n. sp. and
   Chlorethe lalannecassoui n. sp. Three species: Chlorethe ingae,
   Aglaoschema acauna and Cosmoplatidius simulans are recorded for the
   first time from French Guiana and all the species of Compsocerini of
   this region are illustrated. The genera Acabyara and Cosmoplatidius are
   transferred from the tribe Pteroplatini to the tribe Compsocerini. The
   genus Amphidesmus Audinet-Serville, 1834 is transferred to the tribe
   Trachyderini. The tribe Rosaliini LeConte, 1873 is considered as a
   synonym of Compsocerini Thomson, 1864. Thus, the species included in the
   following genera: Rosalia Audinet-Serville, 1833 with Rosalia
   (Eurybatodes) Semenov, 1911, Callichromopsis Chevrolat, 1863 and
   Eduardiella Holzschuh, 1993 must be transferred into the tribe
   Compsocerini.
C1 Dalens, Pierre-Henri; 18 lotissement Amaryllis, F-97354 Remire-Montjoly,
   France, France.

PT J
AN ZOOR14703022524
DT Article
TI Caprellids (Crustacea: Amphipoda) from India.
AU Guerra-Garcia, J.M. (jmguerra@us.es) 
   Ganesh, T.
   Jaikumar, M.
   Raman, A.V.
SO Helgoland Marine Research
VL 64
IS 4
PS 297-310
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The caprellid fauna of India is investigated. A total of 538 samples
   (including algae, seagrasses, sponges, hydroids, ascidians, bryozoans,
   encrusted dead corals, coral rubble, fine and coarse sediments) were
   collected from 39 stations along the coast of India, covering a wide
   diversity of habitats from intertidal to 12 m water depth. A new species
   (Jigurru longimanus n.sp.) is described, and figures of the 11 valid
   species reported so far from India are given together with a key for
   their identification. No caprellids were found in sediments from the
   northeast (16-20[degree]N) coast of India while they were abundant in
   the southeast and west coast. Decreases in salinity due to river
   discharges associated with lower values of oxygen, higher water
   temperatures and lower nutrient inputs along the east coast could
   explain these differences in caprellid composition between the two
   coastlines. Significantly, lower abundance of caprellids in India, as in
   other tropical ecosystems, is probably related to the lack of species
   belonging to the genus Caprella, which reach very high abundances in
   temperate waters.
C1 Guerra-Garcia, J.M.; Univ Sevilla, Fac Biol, Avda Reina Mercedes 6,
   Sevilla, Spain, Spain.
EM jmguerra@us.es
RI Thiruchitrambalam, Ganesh/X-4016-2019; Guerra-Garcia, Jose
   Manuel/P-1700-2014
OI Thiruchitrambalam, Ganesh/0000-0001-9938-3483; Guerra-Garcia, Jose
   Manuel/0000-0001-6050-4997
SC Zoology
SN 1438-387X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones; Indian
   Ocean

   list; systematics; records]. 
   Jigurru longimanus [North Indian Ocean / India, Tamil Nadu / New
   species].

   305]. 
   Jigurru longimanus (Amphipoda): [Sp nov, India, Tamil Nadu (marine), P.
   301].

DT Article
TI Population characteristics of Phthiraptera occurring on Red Whiskered
   Bulbul (Pycnonotus jocosus).
AU Arya, Gaurav
   Bansal, Nayanci
   Khan, Vikram
   Ahmad, Aftab
   Saxena, A.K. (akscsir@rediffmail.com) 
SO Journal of Applied and Natural Science
VL 2
IS 2
PS 263-265
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two phthirapteran species, Menacanthus eurysternus (Amblycera) and
   Brueelia sp. (Ischnocera) were recovered from 100 Red Whiskered Bulbuls
   (Pycnonotus jocosus) during March to December 2006. The occurrence of
   both the phthirapteran species on the aforesaid host are new host
   records. The prevalence, intensity of infestation, range of infestation,
   variance to mean ratio, sex ratio, adult nymph ratio, index of
   discrepancy (D) and exponent of negative binomial (k) were computed. The
   frequency distributionpattern of M. eurysternus conforms to negative
   binomial model. The frequency distribution pattern of Brueelia sp. was
   skewed but not described by the negative binomial.
C1 Saxena, A.K.; Department of Zoology, Govt. Raza P. G. College, Rampur
   (U.P.), India, India.
EM akscsir@rediffmail.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology

DT Article
TI The occurrence of a new species of Gomphocythere (Ostracoda,
   Limnocytheridae) in the Holocene of SE Turkey: the northernmost record
   for the genus.
AU Boomer, Ian (i.boomer@bham.ac.uk) 
   Gearey, Ben
SO Journal of Micropalaeontology
VL 29
IS 2
PS 115-118
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of the genus Gomphocythere (Sars, 1924) from SE Turkey
   extends the known Holocene biogeographical range of this taxon
   northwards by 500 km although only sub-fossil remains have been
   discovered so far. The species has been recorded previously in open
   nomenclature, from a middle Pleistocene site in northern Israel but the
   genus Gomphocythere is particularly abundant and diverse in the large
   lakes of South and East Africa (e.g. Lakes Malawi, Tanganyika and
   Victoria). The closest relative of the new species, based on external
   carapace characteristics, is known to be alive today along one of the
   sources of the River Jordan, central Israel. This suggests the presence
   of a geographically distinct 'northern group' of Gomphocythere separated
   from the majority of known occurrences in eastern and southern Africa.
C1 Boomer, Ian; School of Geography, Earth and Environmental Sciences,
   University of Birmingham, Edgbaston B15 2TT, United Kingdom, United
   Kingdom.
EM i.boomer@bham.ac.uk
RI Gearey, Benjamin R/H-9048-2015; Boomer, Ian/C-5154-2009
OI Boomer, Ian/0000-0003-1276-2179

SN 0262-821X

   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary

AN ZOOR14703024253
DT Article
TI Kataspinifera baumannii: a new genus and species of deep photic
   coccolithophores resembling the non-calcifying haptophyte
   Chrysochromulina.
AU Andruleit, Harald
   Young, Jeremy R. (j.young@nhm.ac.uk) 
SO Journal of Micropalaeontology
VL 29
IS 2
PS 135-147
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB An unusual new coccolithophore species is described from the deep photic
   zone. The species is dimorphic with small body coccoliths bearing short
   spines and larger spine-coccoliths with exceptionally long, hollow,
   quadrate spines. The species is rare but has been observed in the
   Pacific, Indian and Atlantic Oceans reinforcing other evidence that the
   deep photic zone nannoflora is more diverse and heterogeneous than
   previously assumed. The species also shows remarkable morphological
   similarity to some species of the non-calcifying haptophyte
   Chysochromulina of a type which has frequently been cited as evidence
   for possible multiple origins of calcification in haptophytes. However,
   the coccolith structure strongly indicates that the species is a member
   of the Papposphaeraceae. Available phylogenetic data from molecular
   genetics and biomineralization modes make it extremely unlikely that the
   Papposphaeraceae are closely related to the spine-bearing
   Chrysochromulina species and so the striking morphological similarity is
   almost certainly a case of homoeomorphy, and possibly functional
   convergence.
C1 Young, Jeremy R.; Palaeontology Department, The Natural History Museum,
   London SW7 5BD, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM j.young@nhm.ac.uk
OI Young, Jeremy/0000-0001-9320-9804
SC Zoology
SN 0262-821X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Kataspinifera baumannii [Atlantic Ocean /  / New species] [Indian Ocean
   /  / ] [South Pacific / Chile / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Mastigophora, Phytomastigophorea,
   Prymnesiida
OR Kataspinifera (Prymnesiida): [Gen nov, Of family Papposphaeraceae, Type
   species Kataspinifera baumannii, p. 136]. 
   Kataspinifera baumannii (Prymnesiida): [Sp nov, Chile (marine), P. 137].
   
   Papposphaeraceae - Jordan & Young 1990 (Prymnesiida): [Systematics, P.
   135; Emended diagnosis, P. 135]. 
DI 10.1144/0262-821X10-006

PT J
AN ZOOR14703024255
DT Article
TI Evolutionary classification of the Upper Cretaceous (Turonian-lower
   Campanian) planktic foraminifera with incipient meridional
   ornamentation.
AU Georgescu, M. Dan (dgeorge@ucalgary.ca) 
SO Journal of Micropalaeontology
VL 29
IS 2
PS 149-161
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new genus, Fingeria, is recognized among the globular-chambered
   trochospiral planktic foraminifera of the Upper Cretaceous (upper
   Cenomanian[long dash]lower Campanian). It consists of two pre-existing
   species: F. loetterlei (Nauss, 1947) and F. kingi (Trujillo, 1960). The
   ornamentation consists of scattered pustules, which can often fuse to
   form rugosities and, occasionally, costellae, especially over the
   earlier chambers of the test. Meridional ornamentation pattern is
   occasionally developed over isolated chambers. Fingeria is the only
   lineage of the whiteinellid stock that exhibits ornamentation coarsening
   and preferential orientation, which can be meridional or parallel to the
   periphery.
C1 Georgescu, M. Dan; Department of Geoscience, University of Calgary, 2500
   University Drive NW, Calgary, Alberta T2N 1N4, Canada, Canada.
EM dgeorge@ucalgary.ca
SC Zoology
SN 0262-821X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic
DE Fingeria [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Granuloreticulosea,
   Foraminiferida
OR Fingeria (Foraminiferida): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Hedbergellinae, Type
   species Rugoglobigerina kingi Trujillo 1960, p. 151, Cretaceous;
   Fossil]. 
   Fingeria kingi - (Trujillo 1960) (Foraminiferida): [Redescription, P.
   157; Comb nov, Transferred from Whiteinella, p. 157; Fossil]. 
   Fingeria loetterlei - (Nauss 1947) (Foraminiferida): [Redescription, P.
   154; Comb nov, Transferred from Whiteinella, p. 154; Fossil].

TI Creation of the insular genus Sechellalna for Yanga seychellensis
   Distant, cicada devoid of sound organ.
FT Creation du genre Sechellalna pour Yanga seychellensis Distant, 1912.
   Cigale depourvue d'organe sonore (Rhynchota, Cicadidae).
AU Boulard, Michel (mbkcicada01@yahoo.fr) 
SO Lambillionea
VL 110
IS 3
PS 334-337
PD Decembre 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Genus Sechellalna is here created to receive Yanga seychellensis
   Distant, 1912, species of which males lost the faculty to emit sounds
   having, from the original Cicadan sound system, no more than tiny
   sclerified tymbals. Apparently, this new insular genus drives from the
   Madagascan Yanga, taxon of which all the known species possess a
   complete and functional tymbalic device.

TI [Geometrids of H. Hoppe's expeditions to Bioko. Part l: Desmobathrinae,
   Geometrinae (Lepidoptera, Geometridae).]
FT Geometridae der Expeditionen H. Hoppes nach Bioko. 1. Teil:
   Desmobathrinae, Geometrinae (Lepidoptera, Geometridae).
AU Karisch, Timm
SO Lambillionea
VL 110
IS 3
PS 344-352
PD Decembre 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Desmobathrinae and Geometrinae species, collected by H. HOPPE during
   two trips to the island of Bioko, are mentioned with remarks to the
   localities, data and the distribution of each species. HOPPE has found
   at least 33 species of both subfamilies. which is an enormous
   contribution to the knowledge of the islands Geometridae fauna. Three
   new Bathycolpodes species are described, B. scheeli Karisch & Hoppe sp.
   nov. from the island of Bioko, and B. parexplanata Karisch sp. nov. and
   B. roehrichti Karisch sp. nov. from the Coastal region of Cameroun.
   Bathycolpodes subferrata Prout, 1933 stat. nov. from Sao Tome is treated
   as a good species.

AN ZOOR14703022792
DT Article
TI Preliminary study on fouling organisms collected by test panels in
   Shenzhen Bay.
AU Xu, Zhi-bin (zhibing_xu@163.com) 
   Gao, Yang
   Zhang, Jing-huai
   Dong, Yan-hong
   Wu, Shi-wei
SO Marine Environmental Science
VL 29
IS 6
PS 863-865, 878
PD December 2010
PY 2010
NT Article continued on p. 878.
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB From Dec 2006 to Nov 2007, an investigation with exposed test panels on
   the marine fouling organisms was carried out in Shenzhen Bay. 7 Phylum,
   24 species of the fouling organisms were collected in the study. The
   monthly average biomass of the fouling organisms was 2780.72 g/m2 on
   test panels in the surface layer and 4110. 10 g/m2 on test panels in the
   bottom layer, and the highest amount appeared in Jul. The seasonal
   average biomass of the fouling organisms was 2521.13 g/m2 on test panels
   in the surface layer and 4382. 10 g/m2 on test panels in the bottom
   layer, and the highest amount appeared in autumn. The half-yearly
   average biomass of the fouling organisms was 4065. 10 g/m2 on test
   panels in the surface layer and 4298. 30 g/m2 on test panels in the
   bottom layer. The yearly average biomass of the fouling organisms was
   6212.20 g/m2 on test panels in the surface layer and 20009. 10 g/m2 on
   test panels in the bottom layer. The dominant species were different in
   four seasons. The biomass of Hydroides elegans, Bugula neritina and
   balanus sp. were larger in spring and winter, and they didnf grow on the
   panels in summer. The biomass of Mytilopsis sallei and Eudendrium
   racemosum were larger in summer and autumn, and they didn't grow on the
   panels in winter.
C1 Xu, Zhi-bin; South China Sea Environmental Monitoring Center, SOA,
   Guangzhou 510300, China, China.
EM zhibing_xu@163.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1004-1281
BD Animals and man; Damage caused by animals; Damage to man made objects;
   Ecology; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Animalia [Fouling / Seasonal fouling community biomass patterns / Test
   panel surveys] [Biomass /  / ] [Community structure /  / ] [Distribution
   within habitat /  / ] [North Pacific / China, Hong Kong, Shenzhen Bay /
   ]. 
ST Animalia
OR Animalia. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14703022792
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14703024568
DT Article
TI Second distribution record of a single species of the collective group
   Diversibipalium (Plathelminthes, Tricladida, Continenticola,
   Geoplanidae, Bipaliinae) in Wakayama Prefecture, Honshu, Japan, with a
   taxonomic note of new higher classification of the Tricladida.
AU Kubota, Shin
   Kawakatsu, Masaharu
SO Nanki Seibutu
VL 52
IS 2
PS 97-101
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Since the taxonomic system of the Order Tricladida was changed sharply,
   bipaliid land planarians with three genera are placed in the family
   Geoplanidae, the superfamily Geoplanoidea, and the suborder
   Continenticola (Table 1, Fig. 4) . Additionally, non-identified bipaliid
   species are now placed in the collective group Diversibipalium
   KAWAKATSU, OGREN, FROEHLICH et SASAKI, 2002. Therefore, three bipaliid
   species from Wakayama Prefecture reported by KUBOTA, YAMAMOTO &
   KAWAKATSU (2001) should be shown as follows: Bipalium kewense MOSELEY,
   1878; Diversibipalium multilineatum (MAKINO et SHIRASAWA, 1983) (olim
   Bipalium multilineatum MAKINO et SHIRASAWA, 1983: its genital anatomy is
   not known at present) ; Diversibipalium sp. of Tanabe- 1 (olim Bipalium
   sp. Nagasaki- 5 ?) . The fourth bipaliid species found in Wakayama
   Prefecture was reported in the present paper as Diversibipalium sp. of
   Tanabe-2. It is a black species in having a large head plate with a pair
   of well-developed cephalic lappets (Figs 1 [long dash] 3 ) .
C1 Kubota, Shin; Seto Marine Biological Laboratory, Field Science Education
   and Research Center, Kyoto University, Shirahama 459, Nishimuro,
   Wakayama 649-2211, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology
SN 0389-7842
BD Systematics; Taxonomy; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Diversibipalium [Japan / Honshu, Wakayama / New record]. 
TN Invertebrates; Platyhelminths
ST Animalia, Platyhelminthes, Turbellaria
OR Diversibipalium (Turbellaria): [New record]. 
   Tricladida - Lang 1884 (Turbellaria): [Classification, New higher
   classification, p. 99]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14703024568
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14703025271

   Maastrichtian of Nalat-Vad, Hateg Basin, Romania.
AU Csiki, Zoltan (zoltan.csiki@g.unibuc.ro) 
   Codrea, Vlad
   Jipa-Murzea, Catalin
   Godefroit, Pascal
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 258
IS 3
PS 297-324
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Remains of titanosaurian sauropods are common in the Upper Cretaceous
   (Maastrichtian) of the Hateg Basin, Romania, but their usual occurrence
   as either isolated elements or dispersed bones in multitaxon bonebeds
   has hampered the understanding of their detailed anatomy or systematic
   position. The discovery of a partial articulated skeleton in floodplain
   deposits at Nalat-Vad, preserving parts of the vertebral column and
   pelvic girdle, allows for the first time a more detailed understanding
   of the axial anatomy of the Romanian titanosaurs. The specimen is
   described as a new taxon, Paludititan nalatzensis gen. et sp. nov.,
   based on several autapomorphies: presence of an accessory anterior
   centrodiapophyseal lamina in the posterior dorsals; dorsal segments of
   the anterior and posterior centrodiapophyseal laminae parallel in
   posterior dorsals; presence of amphiplatyan mid-caudal vertebrae within
   the procoelous series; anterior caudal vertebrae with narrow neural
   spines showing anteriorly projecting anterodorsal corner, and presence
   of a posterolateral buttress on the iliac peduncle of the ischium. The
   description of Paludititan supports a higher titanosaurian diversity in
   the Hateg assemblage than previously recognized, and will contribute to
   the clarification of the taxonomic status of Magyarosaurus, the only
   titanosaur previously described from the area, and its included species.
   Phylogenetic analyses of Paludititan show it is a relatively derived
   titanosaur, but yields equivocal results as to its more precise
   systematic position and relationships, depending on the dataset used.
   These preliminary results suggest that development of a standard dataset
   for cladistic analyses should represent one of the major tasks of
   sauropod systematics.
C1 Csiki, Zoltan; Univ Bucharest, Fac Geol & Geophys, 1 N Balcescu Blvd,
   Bucharest, Romania, Romania.

DT Article
TI First record of Miocene crustaceans from Hormozgan Province, Southern
   Iran.
AU Vega, Francisco J. (vegver@unam.mx) 
   Gholamalian, Hossein
   Bahrami, Ali
SO Palaeontologische Zeitschrift
VL 84
IS 4
PS 485-493
PD Dec 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Four decapod crustacean species from the Middle Miocene Mishan Formation
   of Hormozgan Province, Southern Iran are described. Three species of
   leucosiid crabs represent the first fossil record for their respective
   genera outside the Indo-Pacific region. The oldest records for Leucosia
   sensu lato, Phylira sensu lato, and Arcania are from Middle Miocene
   deposits of the Indo-Pacific, and thus their paleobiogeographic
   distribution is extended for this lapse of time. Harpactocarcinus
   miocenicus n. sp. represents the youngest and most oriental occurrence
   for a typically Eocene genus, whose species are known mainly from
   Central Europe. This contribution represents the first formal report for
   Tertiary crustaceans from Iran.

TI Description of a new Asaccus (Reptilia: Phyllodactylidae) from Lorestan
   Province, Iran.
FT Beschreibung eines neuen Asaccus (Reptilia: Phyllodactylidae) aus der
   Provinz Lorestan, Iran.
AU Torki, Farhang (torkifarhang@yahoo.com) 
SO Sauria
VL 32
IS 4
PS 3-16
PD Dezember 2010
PY 2010
LA English; German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Asaccus is described from the western Iranian Plateau,
   Lorestan Province. Its morphology is compared in detail to all other
   species defined as yet. Like all other species the new one appears to be
   limited to a small geographical area, and the possible reasons for this
   distribution pattern are discussed. An overview of the distribution
   ranges of all Iranian species is presented, with a new locality for A.
   nasrullahi and an adjusted range for A. elisae.

DT Article
TI In search of the caecilians of the Seychelles.
FT Auf der suche nach den Blindwuehlen der Seychellen.
AU Pawlowski, Sascha (spawlows@gmx.de) 
   Kraemer, Christine
SO Sauria
VL 32
IS 4
PS 43-51
PD Dezember 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Searches for caecilians in the central Seychelles islands of Mahe,
   Praslin and La Digue in 2004, 2007 and 2008 (November/December each)
   yielded only one live adult specimen of Hypogeophis rostratus and
   several road-killed adults of Grandisonia sp. in the area of Beau
   Vallon. Larval stages of Grandisonia alternans were found in 2008 on all
   three islands in the Vallee de Mai (Praslin), Fly Catcher National Park
   (La Digue), Congo Rouge and Beau Vallon Bay (both on Mahe),
   respectively. Finding of both adult and larval caecilians is extremely
   difficult, which suggests that all six endemic species may no longer be
   as common as previously supposed. Contributing factors to their decline
   could be the increasing numbers of domestic chickens in the fringe areas
   of protected areas, the release/escape of pets such as the tenrec, and
   the omnipresence of rats.
C1 Pawlowski, Sascha; Jahnstr. 26, D-68623 Lampertheim, Germany, Germany.
EM spawlows@gmx.de
SC Zoology
SN 0176-9391

   Indian Ocean islands

   [Seychelles /  / biology; distribution; natural history]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Gymnophiona

DT Article
TI Brachiopod and fusulinid assemblages of Kasimovian (Pennsylvanian) age
   from the Andara Massif (Picos de Europa, northern Spain).
AU Martinez Chacon, M. Luisa (mmchacon@geol.unioivi.es) 
   Merino-Tome, Oscar A.
   Villa, Elisa
SO Scripta Geologica Special Issue
VL 7
PS 53-91
PD December 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The analysis of early Kasimovian (Pennsylvanian) brachiopod assemblages
   from two fossiliferous localities of the Las Llacerias Formation (Andara
   Massif, Picos de Europa, northern Spain) improve our knowledge of this
   fossil group in the Cantabrian Zone. At the Morra de Lechugales Peak
   (locality 1), marlstones and bioclastic limestones, accumulated in a low
   energy, subtidal, aphotic setting, characterize a soft muddy sea-floor
   affected by periodic intense bottom currents and provide a rich
   assemblage of brachiopods together with other macrofossils. Brachiopod
   specimens are characterized by their small size (<10 mm) and belong to
   38 different taxa. The fossiliferous dark marly limestones at the
   Castillo del Grajal (locality 2) record a very shallow water, low
   energy, subtidal and photic environment, where bioclastic
   wackestone-packstone accumulated in a relatively clean and clear
   sea-water. Very diverse biotic associations including abundant
   photozoans and heterozoans characterize these strata. Brachiopod
   assemblages from this locality share 12 genera and five species with
   locality 1, but they also show striking differences such as the absence
   in the locality 2 of representatives of the family Spiriferellidae and
   the order Spiriferinida; moreover, the specimens from the last locality
   are of normal size. These differences are interpreted to be the result
   of very different environmental conditions between localities during the
   interval under consideration. Fusulinids studied from the Las Llacerias
   Formation allow correlation of the two fossiliferous localities with the
   lower Kasimovian. The representatives of the family Spiriferellidae are
   described. They include the new species Plicatospiriferella
   winklerprinsi, a small sized form with slightly transverse shell, dorsal
   valve slightly convex, strongly incurved ventral umbo and simple plicae
   on flanks. The new genus Winklerprinsia (type species Winklerprinsia
   europea sp. nov.) is included in the family because of its plicate
   flanks, pustulose microornament, ventral umbonal region thickened by a
   callus and short dental adminicula. The most distinctive feature of the
   new genus is a solid, elevated ventral platform, interpreted as a muscle
   platform. A new fusulinid species, Protriticites winkleri, is described
   from the Morra de Lechugales Peak section. Its overall characteristics
   somewhat resemble forms assigned in other areas of the world to
   Obsoletes, but its wall microstructure corresponds to that of
   Protriticites species.
C1 Martinez Chacon, M. Luisa; Departamento de Geologia, Universidad de
   Oviedo, Arias de Velasco s.n., 33005 Oviedo, Spain, Spain.
EM mmchacon@geol.unioivi.es
SC Zoology
SN 0922-4564

   Winklerprinsia europea [Spain /  / new species] [Carboniferous /  / ]. 
   Winklerprinsia [Carboniferous /  / New genus].
